See the Graduate Program Coordinator for procedure and paperwork.If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Academic Seminar I
college: University College

name: College Transition Seminar
college: University College
Description:
This course offers entering students an opportunity to be part of a class planned specifically for first-year students. The transition to university living and learning is an important one. The course is designed to help students make this passage as smooth as possible. Class sessions focus on topics such as defining college culture, refining study and test-taking skills, identifying personal values, and setting goals. The course is set up in small sections with a premium on classroom discussion. Most sections meet twice per week during the first 8 weeks of the semester. Assignments emphasize self-reflection and improvement, but also seek to acquaint students with the information and skills they need to thrive at The University of Iowa.
The course is part of a Courses In Common Option.  It is taken in combination with a General Education lecture course and the College Transition Workshop course.  Should a student choose to drop this course (College Transition Seminar) they will be required to drop the College Transition Workshop course as well.

name: College Transition Workshop
college: University College
Description:
The College Transition Workshop is designed to provide students with a supervised exposure to effective study skills and a practical context in which these skills can be applied, evaluated, and refined.  To do this the College Transition Workshop is a part of a College Transition Option with both The College Transition Seminar and a shared General Education course.  The College Transition Workshop experience will require you to apply the study skills you are learning in the College Transition Seminar to your study of the material presented in the shared General Education course.  The College Transition Workshop will consist of two 50 minute study sessions per week led by an honors student who has previously taken the shared General Education course.  This student will share study techniques and model the habits of a successful student.  A series of course readings and assignments will deepen your study skills.  The College Transition Workshop experience will expand your study skills repertoire, enhance your understanding of the material in the shared General Education course, and provide you with a skill set that serves you well in the future.
The courses in the College Transition Options are considered as a package through One-Click courses.  Therefore, students should expect to remain in all three courses.  Any exceptions to this should be discussed with your academic advisor.The courses in this category are eligible for Courses In Common Options

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Journey to Medical School
college: University College
Description:
Understand the rewards and demands of being a premedical student. Design your college education in order realize your academic dreams. We will have in-depth conversations with medical students and undergraduates who are applying to medical school. We will read motivational theory and watch TED Talks. We will read poetry by William Carlos Williams, MD and articles by Atul Gawande, MD.
Students will keep a journal, give a group presentation, and write several short papers analyzing what we read and watch. The final project is a personal reflection about your own academic journey.
Each class session will address a specific topic:
Part One: Develop an Internal Locus of Control1. Create a life you love. Be authentic. Understand your values and abilities. Keep a journal.2. Build a network and a safety net. Find mentors and formulate Three Plan A’s. 3. Discover opportunities on campus. Learn about ways to interact with patients. 4. Master difficult course work.
Part Two: Develop Knowledge 5. Students from Carver College of Medicine will describe the life of a medical student at Iowa.6. What is Mindfulness and how does it relate to medicine? What is Mindset?7. Who inspires us? We will give presentations on famous physicians.8. What is Public Health? Learn about the graduate and undergraduate programs at Iowa.9. What is Global Health? Learn about opportunities to make a difference worldwide.
Part Three: Reflect. Is this the path for me? 10. Now that you are far more knowledgeable, decide if medical school is right for you. If so, write a Personal Statement explaining why medicine is an ideal future for you. If not, write an essay describing your exciting new dream."

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Us Versus Them: Creating Empathy Through Narrative
college: University College
Description:
In this course we will examine the power of stories—fiction, memoir, poetry, and tv/film—to create empathy for those who are different than us. As we engage with narratives by and about people from a variety of backgrounds, we will ask what these stories teach us about cultures and experiences not our own. We will reflect on ways that reading affects us and expands our empathy toward those who experience discrimination. We will ask how empathy can be useful, and examine its importance to society.
Each class period we will analyze short reading assignments in a discussion format. Students will be evaluated on participation in class discussion, informal writing assignments, short researched writing assignments, and a final presentation.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            University of Iowa Unwrapped: Exploring Hidden Hawkeye Places
college: University College
Description:
Established in 1847, Iowa has won international recognition for its wealth of achievements in the arts, sciences, humanities, and athletics. These achievements have been supported through the forethought and planning of facilities to support educational and co-curricular activities. The University of Iowa is home to research facilities, athletic venues, historical buildings, and state-of-the-art technology. This First-Year Seminar will unwrap the history, purpose, and functionality of various facilities across campus and in the community. Students will interact with expert faculty and staff members to better understand the hidden secrets of the University of Iowa.
Students will discover the first building owned by the University of Iowa at the Old Capitol Museum; cheer on Hawkeyes with a behind the scenes tour of Kinnick Stadium; understand what makes Iowa a leader in research and academics; and unwrap many other exciting hidden Hawkeye places across campus.  Students will be evaluated through course participation and reflective journals after visiting facilities. The students will also reflect on the topics of appreciation and adjustment to college. We also focus on StrengthsFinder and how the students’ strengths will assist them in meeting the Iowa Challenge.
The course will meet for 100 minutes each week for 8 weeks. Course will meet on Wednesdays from 3:30 pm to 5:10 pm. The first class will be August 30, 2017, and the last class October 18, 2017.
The course is limited to 18 students due to tour sizes. Proposed locations include:1. Old Capitol2. Raptor Center3. Kinnick Stadium4. Hancher Auditorium 5. Public Safety6. President’s Residence7. Voxman Music Building

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Inside Look at College Athletics
college: University College
Description: Inside Look at College Athletics allows first-year students to explore the function of multiple departments within a major intercollegiate athletic program. It provides students access to staff within those areas and the opportunity to critically examine their degree paths and daily job responsibilities. Students will be encouraged to actively apply their knowledge learned in class to actual experiences related to college sports. The goal of the class is to provide students with an understanding of how various units work collaboratively to support the athletics department.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Connecting Skills and Attributes in Healthcare Careers
college: University College
Description: Are you thinking of medical school or nursing but not sure if it is right for you? Have you ever heard of an Epidemiologist or Occupational Therapist? If you know you want a health career but are unsure of all the options and which one might be right for you, this seminar students will teach you about the wide variety of careers in healthcare and what it takes to be successful in them. Find out why dentists often take art classes in college or why pharmacists need to know economics. Requirements include weekly reading assignments, active participation in class, three personal reflections and a final presentation on a chosen health career.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            The Women of Science Fiction
college: University College
Description: Science fiction has always been by, for, and about women. If this statement strikes you as controversial, it’s because science fiction’s publishers and fan communities have so often sought to define and police the genre’s borders to exclude women. But a science fiction canon that ignores half its authors and readers—and frequently the most provocative, political, boundary-pushing half—plays into the worst stereotypes of the genre and tells only a fraction of its own story. This seminar traces the history of twentieth century American science fiction by following the women. We will read a series of short stories and essays that take up questions of sex, gender, sexuality, and embodiment—and that turn their gaze inward to consider the place of these concerns within science fiction as a field. Our objective will be to develop a richer and more complete understanding of this literary genre—one that not only makes room for but is structured around participants of all genders. Readings will include work by Merril, Heinlein, Delaney, Zoline, Le Guin, Russ, Tiptree, Butler, Atwood, and Fowler. Writing assignments will be a series of informal two-page responses. There will be some mini-lectures and film excerpts, but this course will be mostly discussion-based.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Neurodegenerative Diseases
college: University College
Description:
Neurodegenerative diseases and injury to the eye and brain, such as traumatic brain injury or glaucoma, typically lead to progressive deterioration of neurons. These diseases can result from genetic susceptibility, a medical condition, toxins, chemicals, viruses or from unknown causes. Degenerative nerve disease can be serious and/or life threatening and adversely impact the quality of life for affected individuals. These diseases may affect multiple bodily functions in addition to the eye and brain. Importantly, most neurodegenerative diseases have no cure. The treatments designed for these diseases may help to improve symptoms, but do not offer lasting relief from the disease.
In this course we will explore how neurodegenerative diseases affect the human body, the societal and psychological impact of the disease on affected individuals, current treatments for these diseases and emerging research into new therapies for these diseases.
The goal of this course is for students to broadly understand how neurodegenerative diseases cause impairment of bodily functions and to offer insight on how this affects patients and their families. This course will be a highly interactive course with discussion and student group presentations. Assessment and grading for the course will be based on class participation and short writing assignments.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Children's Books Are Serious Business
college: University College
Description: Long ago, children were taught to read the Bible and moralistic texts that modeled virtuous lives. Today, publishing for children is big business, as Harry Potter and other books have shown. The path from the Puritans’ hornbooks and the Sunday School literature of the 19th century to recent best-sellers illustrates the changing status of children and the books written for them. This course covers book awards, celebrity authors, book banning, and rare and collectible children’s books in the UI Libraries. Grades will be based upon participation, short reading journals, and a final essay or book trailer.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Alternative Facts and Bob's Burgers: Deconstructing Media in Society
college: University College
Description: Young adult internet users continue to be the heaviest consumers of online video. Media permeates the fabric of our daily lives and can play a large role in the outcome of current events. We will develop an understanding of cultural influences on media formats, identify dominant cultural ideologies and norms and evaluate media content based on our own experiences, beliefs and values. This seminar will look at media as an information and entertainment source. Throughout the semester we will examine, interpret and evaluate different formats, including streaming video, podcasts, and social media. We will analyze a variety of content touching on cultural topics such as race, class, gender, religion, sexuality and politics. We will assess bias, stereotypes and information silos. We will identify and discuss the social, cultural and political implications of media in society. Students will understand the process of creating media and will be able to make sense of and control their media environment. Students will be able to participate effectively and more objectively in larger national dialogues. Each week we will engage in in-class screenings, activities and discussions. Students will complete weekly assignments and the semester will end with a multimodal presentation that requires the students to synthesize information gained throughout the semester.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Young, Scrappy, and Hungry: Exploring the World of Broadway's Hamilton
college: University College
Description:
Do not throw away your shot…to immerse yourself in the cultural phenomenon that is Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Hamilton. Grounded in hip-hop, and embracing the intersection of history and theatre, it has captivated audiences since it opened. What is it that resonates with such a wide and diverse fan base?
In this course, students will be asked to critically examine themes represented in the musical as well as related topics such as Hamilton fandom and its influence on popular culture. Topics may include race/ethnicity, gender, politics, historical accuracy, musical influences or composition, parallels to current events, etc.
Each class period, through video clips, short readings, and in-class activities we will explore all things Hamilton. Student interests will drive the content. Grades will be based on class participation, brief class assignments, and class “conversations.”

name: First-Year Seminar                                            International Human Rights Law: An Introduction
college: University College
Description:
This course seeks to introduce students to the world of international human rights law and policy. The course will examine questions such as:
• What are human rights?• Who decides whether something is or isn’t a human right?• What can someone do if their human rights have been violated?• What role do nations, NGOs, and corporations play in the enforcement of human rights laws?
The goal of the course is to educate students on the basics of human rights and to have lively discussions about the pros and cons of the systems that already exist as well as generate ideas for how to improve the general human rights situation across the globe.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            You at Your Best: Using Positive Psychology to Thrive
college: University College
Description:
Positive psychology is the study of the strengths and virtues that allows individuals and communities to thrive. In this course, students will learn about key aspects of positive psychology to promote the experience of positive emotion, engagement, and meaning in their lives.
Students will discover their own personal strengths through experiential exercises and activities designed to promote positive emotions, including laughter! We will explore positive emotions through examining contentment in the past, happiness in the present, and hope for the future. We will engage in some basic mindfulness exercises, as the practice of mindfulness has been shown to activate areas of the brain associated with positive emotion. We will also explore individual traits that help students thrive in their various life roles, and to discover how to use their strengths in new and creative ways.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Global Childhood
college: University College
Description: Do children have human rights? What does the law have to say about children and childhood? Should the answers to these questions be the same everywhere? This course takes a global perspective on issues such as adoption and foster care, education and child labor, juvenile crime and punishment, child trafficking and exploitation, migrant and refugee children, and child soldiers. Students will be introduced to primary legal materials including landmark cases from the U.S. Supreme Court and international treaties such as the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child. We will also read excerpts from fiction and memoirs to explore how childhood is experienced and constructed at home and around the world. Grades will be based on class participation, several short papers, and a final class presentation.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            "Wild" at Iowa
college: University College
Description:
Are you interested in spending time outdoors? Did you know that as a student at the University of Iowa you have the opportunity to go backpacking in the Grand Canyon, mountain biking in Moab, canoeing at Big Bend National Park, kayaking at Lake Powell and much more! You can learn to scuba dive, rock climb, kayak, garden, even train for a marathon. This class is an introduction to outdoor recreation and education at Iowa. You’ll explore the natural and recreational areas on and around the University of Iowa campus while learning about the physical and mental health benefits of spending time in the outdoors.
Classes will consist of field trips to try your hand at the indoor climbing wall and the challenge course as well as opportunities to tour the University of Iowa’s Outdoor Rental Center, Iowa Raptor Project, School of the Wild, Sailing Club, P. Sue Beckwith, M.D. Boathouse and the MacBride Natural History Museum. You’ll learn how to take advantage of the many programs the University of Iowa has to offer for enjoying time in the outdoors to improve your physical, mental and intellectual well-being. You’ll develop a plan for how you can include time in the outdoors as a part of your weekly routine. Grading will be based on participation (30%), journaling (20%), reflections (20%) and final project (30%).

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Preparing for Premed: Strategies for Success
college: University College
Description:
So you want to be a doctor? There are many requirements students need to fulfill during their undergraduate experience to best prepare for a career in medicine, even going beyond academic requirements. This seminar seeks to help students connect career and academic planning for a pre-med pathway, while at the same time, helping students learn more about the importance of positive out-of-class behaviors necessary for meeting their goals.
Course Goal: Using a narrative development framework, students will gain competencies and self-awareness that will enable them to successfully transition into and maneuver the premedicine requirements and the transition to college life.
Course Objectives: Through assignments, discussions, course readings, and experiential activities, students will:

Engage in critical analysis, reflection, and storytelling.
Consider opportunities, campus resources, and skills central to success as a pre-med student.
Learn to apply strategies to situations commonly experienced during the first year as a premed student including: academic adjustment, goal-setting, decision-making, time management, navigating premed requirements, building rapport and finding mentorship, studying for retention and recall, case-based learning, and negotiating differences on campus.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Refugee Lives and International Law
college: University College
Description: This course will introduce students to the modern concept of a refugee arising from the 1951 Refugee Convention, and the evolution of the concept both international and domestic contexts. It will also examine current refugee crises, their origins and proposed solutions, around the world.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Methods of Legal Persuasion
college: University College
Description: Clarence Darrow. Leslie Abramson. Johnnie Cochran. What do these people have in common? They are (or were) all trial lawyers. Love them or hate them, they knew how to use their words—written and spoken—to persuade. In this class, you will be introduced to the basics of legal persuasion. Learn what a legal brief is, get to know the basic sources of law, and develop techniques in, well, getting your way.

name: Peer Led Undergraduate Study (PLUS)                                            Quantitative Problem Solving in General Chemistry I
college: University College
Description:
PLUS: Quantitative Problem Solving in General Chemistry I is designed for students enrolled in both General Chemistry I (CHEM:1070) and College Algebra (MATH:1005). PLUS is organized and facilitated by an undergraduate student who has been successful in both chemistry and math courses at the University of Iowa.
Collaborative activities and discussions are used to highlight challenging concepts from both algebra and chemistry. The small size of PLUS-sections enables students from large courses to better connect with peers and work together toward common goals. This structure has been shown to save students time, to make studying more effective, and to enhance learning in subjects involving complex concepts. PLUS meets twice per week for 50 minutes throughout the semester.

name: Exploring Social Justice
college: University College

name: Steps to Success for TRiO: Step I
college: University College
Description: This course is designed to assist first year TRiO SSS student learn about and adjust to the university. It is a 12 week course. Some campus partners, UI staff members who are committed to help TRiO SSS students survive and thrive, will visit the class to share their knowledge and wisdom. Students will complete readings and reflect in writing and in discussions about their own adjustment experiences, which will include their shared and unique challenges, strengths, and new learning.

college: University College

college: University College

name: The Passport Project                                            Exploring Iowa and Iowa City
college: University College
Description:
The Passport Project is a weekly, one-semester hour cultural engagement seminar recommended especially for students new to the University of Iowa. Passport participants have the opportunity to explore the rich cultural offerings of University and Iowa City by attending twelve events over the course of the semester.  As a part of the class students attend at least one event in each of the following categories:

Performing Arts
Visual Arts
Humanities
Global Perspectives
Science and Engineering
Social Sciences
Life at Iowa

After attending an event of their choice, students create and post a short written or multimedia reflection on the event that includes ideas the experience may have sparked. Events range from concerts, science demonstrations, art workshops and plays to a Hawkeye football game. In-class activities include presentations from the Passport Team and distinguished leaders in a range of fields – medicine, astrophysics, and the arts, and breakout group sessions led by Peer Mentor Passport graduates.

name: Passport Project Colloquium                                            Innovative Approaches to Leading Small Groups in a Large Class
college: University College
Description: Activities and assignments for Peer Mentors involved in ARTS:1450:0001 and CSI:1450:0001 include: short readings and media screenings related to innovative and best practices in learning and teaching; development of strategies for the encouragement of online public multimedia writing; collaborate on the development of guidelines and hand-outs for effective leadership in small group meetings; syllabus and lesson plan development;informal presentations and reflections; guest speakers; panel discussions; in depth dialog on enhancing the educational and social experience of First-Year students at Iowa; and writing a final reflection on their Colloquium and Passport Project experience at the end of semester.

name: Athletic Transition Seminar                                            Introduction to the Hawkeye Life Program
college: University College

college: University College

name: Success at Iowa
college: University College
Description: Success at Iowa is required for all new first-year and transfer students, and is designed to help students transition successfully to the University of Iowa. This course will introduce students to online tools that are specific to the University of Iowa, and also includes information related to campus resources and services, Financial Aid Literacy, strategies for making healthy behavioral choices, sexual assault awareness and prevention, diversity awareness, mental health, and a comprehensive transitional survey. The course is divided into several parts (each with its own due date), and is composed of a series of modules. Students complete the Introduction and Part 1 of the course before participating in an orientation program. There are no class meetings or textbooks to purchase; everything you need is online.Restricted to entering transfer students, UG, Handling Code B.

name: The Transfer Transition
college: University College
Description: This course offers transfer students an opportunity to be part of a new class planned specifically for them. The transition to The University of Iowa is an important one. This course is designed to help transfer students make this passage as smooth as possible. Class sessions focus on topics such as defining The University of Iowa culture, discovering university resources, choosing careers and majors, refining study skills, taking tests, identifying personal values, exploring self-motivation, and setting goals. The course is set up in small sections with a premium on classroom discussion. Assignments emphasize self-reflection and improvement, but also seek to acquaint students with the information and skills they need to thrive at The University of Iowa.Restricted to entering transfer students, UG, Handling Code B.

Description: This course is offered through the CIMBA Italy study abroad program. Classes are held in Paderno del Grappa, Italy. Enrollment is restricted to participants in this study abroad program. Please contact the CIMBA Italy office at 319-335-0920 for additional information.

name: Communication Skills for Leadership
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This section is offered through the Division of Continuing Education (DCE). This section will be conducted asynchronously online. Several virtual, synchronous, small-group meetings will be required. A webcam, USB headset with microphone, and hardwired Internet connection are required.
New or returning students unable to register directly on MyUI click here to proceed. Contact DCE at 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Organizational Leadership
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Introduction to nature of leadership, styles of leadership that are most effective, and ways in which obstacles may be overcome in groups or organizations; different approaches to qualities of leadership, role of visions and motivation, interpersonal and decision-making skills, meeting preparation and evaluation, and related communication skills.
 This course requires two (2) online proctored examinations.

Local students will take exams in the DCE Testing Center (no charge).
Off-campus students will take exams using an online proctored exam service. Off-campus students must have access to a computer with a webcam and headset/microphone in a quiet/private location. Off-campus students are responsible for proctoring fees (up to $20 per exam).
This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Gender, Communication, and Culture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Gender roles and communication processes; function of communication in gender role development.  
 If you are not a member of the University of Iowa Honors Program, you may contact the course instructor in order to request permission to enroll.

name: Black TV Drama: The Wire
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course examines the social and political impact of television dramas featuring people of African descent in the West through the example of HBO's The Wire.  At once social commentary and a commercial and aesthetic force, the series has pioneered new ways of thinking about the relationship between media and society at large, while revolutionizing the ways in which black urban life is portrayed in today's world.  The course focuses on the complex intersections between urban poverty, education, the political system, crime, and mediation in Western society.

name: Gender, Sexuality, and Media
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Media Industries and Organizations
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Global Media Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Media and Democracy
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Nonverbal Communication
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Topics in Communication Studies                                            Social Media and Society
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course provides an introduction to theoretical and critical issues raised by social media for communication, with particular emphasis on cultural and political phenomena.
Topics include various understandings of social media, forms of digital communication, individual and collective identity formations via social media, online communities, and global cultural exchange as well as recent examples of the "viral" phenomenon and "slacktivism" (feel-good, easy activism on social media). Together, we will grapple with questions regarding the effects of social media:
o   How do social media reshape our identity, relationship, culture, economy, and grassroots participation?
o   How does our understanding of media and society affect our use of social media?
o   How do social media reshape the concepts of the public sphere and citizenship?
o   How are global cultural and political scenes affected by social media?  
 
Restriction
The course content is similar to that of COMM 4173:0001. Students who have taken 4173 cannot register for this course.

name: Topics in Communication Studies                                            Sexual Communication in Personal Relationships
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Organizational Communication
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In Organizational Communication, we explore the nature and function of communication in organizations. This course focuses on theoretical concepts and scholarly research in the field of organizational communication. As you prepare for your careers, this course will challenge you to think critically about the diverse perspectives and theories used to understand how communication works in organizational settings. You will have the opportunity to study and apply theories of organizational communication and investigate a number of topics pertinent to organizational life, such as leadership, teamwork, conflict, gender, and globalization.

name: The Invention of Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Introduction to Latin American Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course (taught in English) provides an interdisciplinary introduction to Latin American Studies through a series of integrated discussions of issues from the history (particularly intellectual and cultural history) of the region with examination of how those issues are represented in cultural production (literature, cinema, music, the arts). Focus will be on twentieth century Latin America.

name: Practicum in Debate
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Specialized research, case construction, argument preparation, and practice for intercollegiate policy debate competition.

name: Oral Interpretation
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Experiential Learning in Comm Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Communication skills, knowledge in work assignments related to students' academic and career interests; full- or part-time, on or off campus.

name: Independent Study
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Honors Thesis
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: LGBTQ/Queer Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In the last two decades, it seems like everything has been queered.  We have queer theory/queer politics, queer citizenship, queer performativity, genderqueer, the New Queer cinema, the new New Queer cinema, Queer Eye for the Straight Guy, Queer as Folk—and these are only some of the examples that explicitly use queer as a signifier. It should be clear that the meaning of “queer” is up for grabs as all of these examples employ related but different connotations of the term. The reclamation of “queer” has been a welcome development in some circles, while in others “queer” may connote, among other things, racism, sexism, and/or politically paralyzing theory. Each of these positions is informed by different interpretations of the meaning of “queer,” interpretations that conflict over the importance of one’s identity, actions, and sexuality. We will enter these debates from the perspective of engaged intellectuals, concerned with improving cultural modes of democratic practice. These practices include activities such as the production and consumption of various kinds of media and legal rhetorics, the use of public and private spaces, and the possibilities of coalitional politics. As engaged intellectuals we will allow political practices and academic theorizing to inform one another as each one of us develop our stance on the utility of rhetorics of queer identities, theories, and politics.

name: Globalization and Culture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Family Communication
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Networking America: History of Broadcast
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Introduction to Research and Teaching
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Communication studies as a field of scholarship; election of research problems, major lines of research represented in the department, bibliographical tools for scholarship in the field.

name: Proseminar in Communication Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Health Communication Campaigns
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This graduate seminar will provide you with an insight into theories and concepts developed and explored in communication campaigns and their application to health. In this course we will explore the design and analysis of health campaigns blending theory, practice and methods to critique past, present, and future campaigns. This course will cover a wide range of theories and perspectives on campaigns.

name: Seminar in Rhetorical Theory
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Seminar: Rhetoric and Culture                                            Queer Geographies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Seminar examines queer and trans- theoretical approaches to the study of space and spatiality, across varying scales and regions. Organized by interdisciplinary perspectives from queer studies, communication and media studies, rhetoric, geography, literature, and queer historicism, the focus of the seminar will be how to engage in theoretically informed, contextual, and communicative driven inquiry of queer public cultures, space, and place; from archival resources, field methods, oral histories, and criticism of public discourse.

name: Communication Theory
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Ph.D. Dissertation
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Modern times demand smart writers who know how to tell the truth, even when it hurts. In this class, we'll look closely at what that means: How do skilled authors take true stories and events, and make them into works of art that captivate their readers? The stakes in creative nonfiction are always high, and we'll push ourselves to be brave in the face of dangerous writing through weekly, guided essays and an end-of-semester project tying them together. Along the way, we'll take up the works of Joan Didion, George Orwell, E.B. White, and other essayists to guide us.
Instructor: Robert Peck learned storytelling from his grandfather, a World War II veteran-journalist and European bookmaker. He's the defending Wyoming Press Association columnist of the year, a former collegiate debate coach and speechwriter, an avid birder, and a Pokémon master. Robert's writing—about family, history and stupid amusement park rides—has appeared on Cracked.com and in newspapers from California to Connecticut.

name: The Art and Craft of Creative Nonfiction                                            Ways of Seeing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In 1879, the painter Cezanne announced, “I will astonish Paris with an apple.” How can we, as writers, similarly transform humble apples into great works of art? In this course, we will practice of new ways of seeing and describing the world. Careful description—forestalling the moment of explanation—can challenge our assumptions and lead to unexpected insights. Describing keeps us faithful to the world’s wonder and strangeness; it can preserve its capacity to shock. We will ask: What makes a description transformative? How might narrative emerge from description? And, most importantly, how is the self revealed through the act of description--that is, how is the seer revealed in what they see? We will learn from writers who, through a heightened quality of attention, show us the world in a new way--writers like Claudia Rankine, Sei Shonagon, Annie Dillard, Barry Lopez, Francis Ponge, Virginia Woolf, Jamaica Kincaid, William Maxwell, and David Foster Wallace. With an emphasis on enhancing creative thinking in our everyday lives, we will complete many in-class creative exercises, and through the process of reading, workshopping, and revising, explore the myriad forms and possibilities nonfiction can offer.
Instructor: Anya Ventura is a writer whose work has appeared in the Los Angeles Review of Books, Artforum, Temporary Art Review, and The Rumpus, among others.Required Texts:Citizen: An American Lyric, Claudia Rankine, ISBN-10:1555976905
So Long, See You Tomorrow, William Maxwell, ISBN-10:0679767207

name: The Art and Craft of Personal Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Many writers look inward to solve problems of existence: to make sense of the senseless, to disentangle lies or contradictions, and to heal invisible wounds. Some write to seize the fleeting moment, to declare beauty, and to render private experience more significant. There are a few for whom personal writing is a matter of survival, and only through journeys of reflection can such individuals transcend their limitations and reinvent the world that shapes them. In this course, we will read works by Nick Flynn, Mary Karr, Lucy Grealy, Kathryn Harrison, and others whose vitality seems to depend on introspection. We will examine the kinds of surrender and sacrifice that such writers undergo in pursuit of universal truths, resolution, and transformation. In addition to learning how to map and navigate narratives as personal quests, students will workshop and revise multiple autobiographical works for a portfolio that demonstrates risk, growth, and discovery.
Instructor: Dina Peone is an award-winning poet, essayist, and diarist from the Hudson Valley who, before moving to Iowa, earned a BA at Sarah Lawrence College and facilitated a semester-long workshop in creative writing with incarcerated women. Recently she taught the creative writing master class Funhouse Mirroring: Finding the Self in Unexpected Places and she was nominated by the Rhetoric Department for an Outstanding Teaching Assistant Award. Dina is currently at work on a memoir about a house fire that disfigured and disabled her when she was a morbid teenager.

name: Art and Craft of Environmental Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
From people protesting oil at Standing Rock to glaciers melting at increasing speeds to antibiotic resistant superbugs growing in the hog farms in our own backyard, writing about the environment has never been more necessary. In this class, we’ll look back at writers and activists who brought understanding and clarity to the public, as well as those writers who are pushing the envelope today. As a student, you’ll hear from environmental experts right here on the UI campus, have the chance to investigate regional environmental issues firsthand, and be pushed to experiment with your own interests, producing a series of researched essays. We’ll workshop these essays as a class, and you’ll write a final essay that—who knows—might just change the world.
Instructor: Brittany Borghi is an essayist who has written about permaculture in eastern Iowa, the wonder of Effigy Mounds National Monument, and ideas surrounding modern birth control. A Pittsburgh-native and former TV journalist, she's working on a larger project about death rituals and facelessness

name: Art and Craft of Writing for New Media                                            The Essay Film
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
If the written essay is hard to define, the “essay film” is even more slippery, stretching from Orson Welles to Beyoncé. As part of our class discussion, we’ll cross-pollinate the written word with the filmed image as we study certain essays and watch the films they were turned into. We’ll also screen nearly a dozen stand-alone examples of this wild, endlessly flexible genre and engage in rigorous discussion about just what is an essay film—what conventions it can ignore, what mischief it can get up to, what it can accomplish that a standard documentary cannot. Finally, we’ll set out to craft our very own films using that most ubiquitous of filmic equipment: the camera phone.
No previous film experience is necessary! Nor do you need a mastery of expensive equipment or software; this course will either fill in those gaps or skirt them entirely. We’ll keep to a low-tech aesthetic to reflect the often-rebellious nature of the essay as we film, edit, and workshop our projects, using Tangerine (a feature film shot entirely on an iPhone 5s) as our guiding star.
Instructor: Taney Kurth has written about antique consignment stores, competitive video games, open-heart surgery, the dying process, and deafness. He has most recently published his own essay film about faith and heart defects on Northwestern’s TriQuarterly website.

name: Art and Craft of Immersion Journalism
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
It’s amazing what doors the phrase “I’m a writer” can open—doors to football locker rooms, morgues, prison cells, backstage, train cars, and the realities of people and places otherwise off-limits, secret, or unwritten. A uniquely rewarding type of nonfiction writing, immersion journalism takes grit, empathy, and the time necessary to research deeply important stories. In this class, you will embed within an Iowa City institution or organization in order to practice the art of keen observation and quality note-taking, ultimately emerging with a riveting piece of immersion journalism. Meanwhile, we will read from such diverse writers as Nellie Bly (who went undercover in a mental institution), Richard Preston (who wrote from the frontlines of an infectious disease), Adrian Nicole LeBlanc (who lived with a family for eleven years), Ted Conover, David Foster Wallace, Barbara Ehrenreich, Joe Sacco, and Truman Capote. We will also discuss the ethics and variations of approach to this particularly exciting, absolutely necessary craft.
Instructor: Lucy Schiller is an immersion-oriented essayist whose work has appeared in The New Yorker, Territory, The New Republic, The Rumpus, The Essay Review, and The San Francisco Bay Guardian. She has embedded with arrowhead collectors along the Missouri River, metal detectorists in Oklahoma, and treasure hunters in the Rocky Mountains.

name: Publishing I: Intro Literary Publishing                                            Writing and Editing for Literary Journals
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
You’ve written it—now how do you publish it? This course will investigate the world of publishing, focusing specifically on literary journals, small presses, and our relationship to these outlets as readers, writers, and eventual publishers ourselves. We’ll examine a diverse selection of recently published work, from magazines like Oxford American to The Diagram to The Paris Review, and we’ll talk to the editors who facilitated that work’s exposure, asking them what makes an attractive submission, what their editorial process looks like, how they survive financially, and more. In addition to learning the field’s history and trajectory, we will discuss—and argue, constructively—about the role of publishing today, while confronting the dilemma of what to publish, how to acquire it, and how to get it in the hands of an audience. Most of all, we will strive to become better advocates for our own essays, short stories, and poems, leaving the course able to sharply and smartly articulate our artistic sensibilities to potential readers and editors. This course will include hands-on editorial exercises involving pitching, soliciting, and managing a publication, and will conclude with the production of a literary journal composed of student work.
Instructor: Micah Fields is from Houston, Texas. He has written and published work about Pizza Hut, collage art, hurricanes, and the war in Afghanistan. He is an MFA candidate in the Nonfiction Writing Program, and he’s currently working on a large project about Houston and the Texas coast.

name: Prose Style
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The crafted verbal texture of prose style will guide discussion as both a topic and a goal. This is a course in reading for writing. With illustrations drawn from fiction and nonfiction alike, you will be studying master sentences from great writers in order to master sentences of your own, concentrating on diction and syntax, words and their wording, in a mix of intensive reading and applied writing. Like the word itself slipping from adjective to predicate, modifier to subordinate verb, in that last sentence (lesson # 1 right there), how can the very idea of “mastery” shift over from an attribute recognized to a force activated in your own prose? Here is a course in literature as rhetorical example rather than as interpretive challenge. We will be thinking not so much about the style of geniuses as about the genius of style—and how to plug into its energies, not just by aspiration but by practiced strategies of sentence building from week to week.

name: Personal Writing                                            Portraiture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In this class, we will be examining the idea of portraiture, cataloging the various ways that writers of creative nonfiction have turned to literature to try and work through questions of what it means to see, truly see, the whole of a person, in all their complexities. Does the answer lie in photographic precision? Or is it through impressionistic strokes that encourage a more emotional, psychological interpretation? In what way do we truly find access another person? We will explore the various ways writers have interpreted the idea of the literary self-portrait, from work that seems invite the reader’s direct gaze, to sketches of others that actually end up revealing far more about the writer herself. As we read such writers as Thomas De Quincey, Natalie Diaz, Plutarch, Jo Ann Beard, Montaigne, Alison Bechdel, Virginia Woolf, Marguerite Duras, Joseph Mitchell, James Baldwin, and Zora Neale Hurston, we will be looking to their various interpretations of portraiture to help guide our own writing. And then we will take all this examining and questioning one step further, by doing intensive reflection on our own decisions as writers through the workshop process.

name: Writing for Business and Industry                                            Prepare for the "Real World"
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course prepares students for “real world” writing situations and is based on seminars that I do for companies throughout the Midwest. I also emphasize building a portfolio, resumes, cover letters, and interview skills for job searches. The course teaches techniques for revision--both within sentences for efficiency and clarity and within whole documents for comprehension, persuasion, and coherence. Students revise many kinds of transactional documents, from letters and memos to procedures and reports. All examples are drawn from actual business transactions. Students should emerge from the course with enhanced writing, editing, job search, and managerial skills.
Assignments, papers, exams, projects, special comments etc.
I require one paper every week. I give no exams. Students revise letters, memos, e-mails, reports, and other transactional documents. They also design and/or revise other documents of their own choosing. They work on sentence structure and they create cover letters and resumes, engage in mock interviews, and solve managerial problems. Students draw cartoons as part of their assessment of their job search experiences.

name: Approaches to Teaching Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course explores the idea that to learn to teach writing best, we must write and read; these acts cannot be disconnected. Students read and discuss accounts by professional writers, student writers, teachers of writing, and writing researchers. The discipline of composition studies, as well as reflections by writers on writing, is rich with interesting documentation, important theory, and vigorous dialogue. Students write for an audience to read and respond, in a broad variety of genres including the personal essay, the poem, short fiction, short nonfiction, the letter, the one-pager, and an experimental blur of genres. Writing is one tool for working out thinking. It is a link between inner speech and a frame for talk, a link between writer/speakers and reader/listeners. It is a writing teacher's responsibility to create an environment that ensures a diet of varied writing and broad reading, a community of rich, specific responders, and lots of opportunities for revising and careful editing. Along with the development of the individual writer-reader, the "social construction of knowledge" is an important concept in a writing class, and students experience it in this course. There are no actual stages, there is no specific process, but we can describe and theorize about prewriting techniques, revision strategies, conferencing models, inventories of grammatical conventions and mechanics, and publishing opportunities. Describing writing allows us to freeze the action to discover conditions under which writing takes place, and what the differences are in every writer's approach. To teach writing, you need to see that the act of writing is different with each piece you write, that you contribute to the next piece you write with each piece you read.
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. Area: Nonfiction and Creative Writing.

name: Undergrad Project in Nonfiction Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Students must make arrangements with an instructor and complete the Independent Study contract prior to the start of the semester. Contracts are available on the English Department website at http://www.english.uiowa.edu/undergrad/advising/
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. AREA: Nonfiction and Creative Writing.If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Teaching in a Writing Center
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The primary purpose of this seminar/practicum is to prepare students to work in the Writing Center at the University of Iowa and/or other institutions. A secondary purpose is to introduce students to some important themes in writing studies. Students read articles, books, handouts, and web pages on the following related issues: reading and writing processes, one-on-one conferencing dynamics, second language writing, basic writing, first- and second-year college writing, writing across the curriculum, and writing center administration. Students keep a weekly journal in which they apply course readings to tutoring their own writing center students. An oral report on a case study of a student writer or on a resource for tutoring writing as well as a final written project are required. For more information, please e-mail Carol Severino at carol-severino@uiowa.edu.

name: Teaching Nonfiction
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This is a course for people who intend to be writers and also teachers; in fact, you’re teaching Nonfiction Writing. We will explore the very special issues and questions involved in teaching nonfiction writing. Knowing how to read it and write it is not knowing how to teach it. Given what’s currently available to us, we’ll consider how we determine what assignments, readings, and exercises are best for our students—and for us. What do we mean about “reading like a writer? And how do we teach that?” Another question: you like teaching, you like the idea of being able to get a job, part-time or full-time, teaching writing to college students? In this course, we’ll work with interesting academic resources: articles, books, journals, websites, organizations, conferences, special interest groups. You’ll build an appropriate CV, dossier, cover letter, teaching portfolio, keep track of job announcements, and learn how to write convincing applications. We’ll explore the ever-painful questions about how to assess, evaluate, and grade student writing, what alternatives and complements to grading we have as writing teachers. We’ll investigate writing and publishing writing about teaching. Together, we’ll determine dates, times, and casts of characters for special readings, master classes, Writers Gone Public, pedagogy partners for mutual observations, and class visits.
Books will be at Prairie Lights.

name: Essay Writing Workshop
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This workshop will encourage a rigorous creative reading and writing of creative nonfiction, with special attention paid to place, pace and identity. We will also be discussing a few outside authors, including Jesmyn Ward, Rachel Kaadzi, James Baldwin, Sarah Gerard and Angela Morales.
This course will be taught by Kiese Laymon, the author of Long Division and How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America, which was named one of the best books of the year by Buzzfeed, The Believer, Salon, Guernica, Contemporary Literature, Mosaic Magazine, Library Journal, The Chicago Tribune and the Crunk Feminist Collective. He is a regular contributor to The Los Angeles Times, The Guardian, Oxford American, ESPN, and Guernica.

name: Nonfiction Writing Workshop                                            Radio Essays
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: We’ve all been told how important it is to “find your voice” as a writer. This has been especially true in the world of literary nonfiction where voice is shorthand for aesthetic or rhetorical artistry. Yet written texts don’t really have voices. They may be teeming with stylistic codes, but those are quiet things. In the silence of the printed word, voice is at best a trope for the formal construction of a work across different stylistic registers. Not so in the case of radio where voice means vocalization, where words sound off. When an essay learns how to speak, when it has a real “voice,” what can it say? In this workshop, we’ll explore voice quite literally as an acoustic event by experimenting with three modes of radiophonic nonfiction—narrative, essayistic, and documentary (students will complete projects in two out of three of these genres). Along with a good deal of revising, we will do close readings and critiques of student work, in both written and radiophonic form, as well as read and listen to selected radio essayists and sound artists. Each student’s written and studio work will receive at least two formal workshops over the course of the semester. The goal of this class is to help you discover, develop, and strengthen your capacities as a writer of artful nonfiction that is as compelling to the ear as to the eye. You’ll use the English Department’s media studio for sound work, learning how to produce voiceovers, record interviews, capture sounds and music, and edit these things with spoken texts.

name: Graduate Thesis Workshop
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In this graduate thesis workshop, which is a requirement for all 3rd year students in the NWP, we will consider the special concerns of writers who are engaged in extended and serious works-in-progress, and how we can serve as effective and rigorous editors for others' evolving projects. Over the course of the term, we will devote time to helping one another conceptually, as well as with practical questions of productivity, process and research. And finally, as we workshop a significant portion of each of your theses, we will pay special attention to literary mastery-- how to push ourselves and others toward high standards of craft throughout a book-length project, through multiple revisions and iterations.

name: Readings in Nonfiction                                            Autobiographical Narrative Writing in the Age of Obama, Trump, the Internet, the 24-Hour News Cycle, and You
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The course will ask writers to consider how explicitly political autobiographical art-making is created, shared, liked, retweeted and maybe read in a genre reliant on news-pegs, social media activism and varying renditions of wokeness. Some possible authors we will discuss and read in this course include Zandria Robinson, Hua Hsu, Roxane Gay, Samantha Irby and Hari Zyad.
This course will be taught by Kiese Laymon, the author of Long Division and How to Slowly Kill Yourself and Others in America, which was named one of the best books of the year by Buzzfeed, The Believer, Salon, Guernica, Contemporary Literature, Mosaic Magazine, Library Journal, The Chicago Tribune and the Crunk Feminist Collective. He is a regular contributor to The Los Angeles Times, The Guardian, Oxford American, ESPN, and Guernica.

name: Forms of the Essay                                            History of the Essay
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
"That immense framework and planking of concepts to which the needy man clings his whole life long in order to preserve himself," wrote Friedrich Nietzsche, "is nothing but a scaffolding and toy for the most audacious feats of the liberated intellect." In this class, we will build a toy for audacious feats of intellect. We will build a scaffolding for the needy part of us that requires conceptual order. That is to say, we will write a history that you, in your liberated state, will challenge and resist.
We'll start with the Tablet of Cebes, which either was or was not authored by Cebes, either four centuries before the Common Era or one century into it, and press forward from there. Along the way you'll be encouraged to develop and defend a particular definition of the essay. "What makes this text essayistic?" we'll ask. "What distinguishes it from fiction or poetry?"
Expect to explore connections between: Thomas de Quincey, Lucretius, Friedrich Nietzsche, Plato, Joan Didion, Marcus Aurelius, William Blake, James Baldwin, Richard Rodriguez, Porphyry, Arthur Schopenhauer, Julio Cortázar, Clarice Lispector, Annie Dillard, Antonin Artaud, and many others. You'll write short critical essays in response to our eclectic texts, and give a presentation or two.
This course is mandatory for all first-year students in the Nonfiction Writing Program, who will emerge with shared context, both textual and conceptual, for the genre. It is also open to graduate students of all stripes who have permission to take it.

name: Approaches to Nonfiction                                            Performance Writing, Criticism, and the Essay
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Many writers are initially taught that becoming a critic demands they place themselves at an analytical and rhetorical remove from their objects of study – or, at least, to adopt a prose style that enables them to convincingly fake such distance. “Performative writing,” as Della Pollock influentially described it in 1998, is not solely “a matter of formal style,” but rather a “discursive practice” that is “an important, dangerous, and difficult intervention into routine representations of social/performative life.” Emerging in the wake of poststructuralist theories, especially as taken up in the fields of anthropology, performance studies, and feminist, gender, and queer studies, performative criticism seeks not to describe or to analyze but rather to do. The term has been defined variably, but it is not merely a synonym for “creative essay.” In this course, we will read and respond to a selection of the diverse theories and practices that can be aligned under the flickering sign of this growing anti-genre. The syllabus may include writing by Pollock, Kathy Acker, Gloria Anzaldúa, Antonin Artaud, J.L. Austin, Roland Barthes, Barbara Browning, Judith Butler, Hélène Cixous, Jacques Derrida, Tim Etchells, Guillermo Gómez-Peña, Matthew Goulish, Adrian Heathfield, bell hooks, Wayne Koestenbaum, Fred Moten, José Esteban Muñoz, Peggy Phelan, Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick, and Michael Taussig, among others. Assignments will include weekly informal reading responses, one short (5-page) essay, and one longer (15-page+) essay.
 
The following required texts are available at Prairie Lights:
Barthes, Roland. Image-Music-Text. Translated by Stephen Heath. New York: Hill and Wang, 1978. ISBN 978-0374521363
Goulish, Matthew. 39 Microlectures: In Proximity of Performance. London: Routledge, 2002. ISBN 978-0-415213936
Koestenbaum, Wayne. The Queen's Throat: Opera, Homosexuality, and the Mystery of Desire. New York: Da Capo, 2001. ISBN 978-0-306810084
Schneider, Rebecca. Performing Remains: Art and War in Times of Theatrical Reenactment. London: Routledge, 2011, ISBN 978-0-415-40442-6

name: Special Project in Nonfiction Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Thesis in Nonfiction Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Drawn into Learning: Use Cartoons to Improve Your Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
“Memory is a kind of accomplishment”, says the poet William Carlos Williams and this course will help you take control of your learning process and remember what you learn. Record, compose, and apply your first college experiences as a series of stories and images. Use cartoons to improve your writing. You will explore new ways to map your experiences and work with others. You can cartoon without previous drawing experience or drawing skill. Study the work of those who use journals that reflect on their life experiences. Talk with some of these artists and writers who will come to class. Write and draw in class workshops. Go home and compose in your journal. I will grade your class participation, daily and weekly journal exercises, and your course project.
Assignments, papers, projects, special comments etc.
Students draw cartoons and make journal entries. They will also create a course project: a sequence of cartoons and writing. I will grade class participation, daily and weekly journal exercises, and the course project. I give no exams.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            Celebrity in Contemporary America
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Was Andy Warhol right when he clamed in 1968 that "In the future, everyone will be world-famous for 15 minutes?" What does it mean that certain celebrities are now famous for being famous? And why do we spend so much time and energy commenting on these issues? This class provides students with an opportunity to study the meaning of celebrity in contemporary America. We will examine a wide range of artistic (Warhol's “screen tests”), literary (Bright Lights, Big City, Reality Hunger: A Manifesto), cinematic (Natural Born Killers, Almost Famous), televisual (Keeping up with the Kardashians), musical (Kanye West), digital (the Youtube star phenomenon), political (Clinton, Obama, Trump) and scholarly (The Frenzy of Renown) engagements with these challenging topics. We will also analyze the way in which the old and new media have generated provocative opportunities for the creation and analysis of celebrity. Students will be expected to speak in class, keep a journal, and write one short essay.

name: City of Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course will cover the literary history of Iowa City from the founding of the Writers’ Workshop up through its designation as a UNESCO City of Literature. We will read poems, short stories, novels and essays by faculty and graduates of the Workshop, International Writing Program, and Nonfiction Writing Program alongside reminiscences by writers of their time in Iowa City. Lectures will cover such topics as the short story and the lyric poem as pedagogical models, the problem of whether writing can be taught, the role of literary prizes and awards, the significance of local businesses such as Prairie Lights and the Foxhead tavern, the rise of creative nonfiction, and the idea of a Writing University. Assignments have been designed to engage students with the university and the city.
Assignments: Midterm and Final Exam. Book report. Creative Pastiche. Participation on course WordPress site.
Grading: Midterm: 20%; Final: 20%; Author bio: 20%; Creative Pastiche: 20%;
Participation: 20%.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Intimate Knowledges
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
We tend to think of intimacy as an essentially romantic disposition. Given that intimacy typically signals close proximity— both emotionally and physically— this is unsurprising. Such proximity also suggests a kind of sharing, of knowledge in particular, which in turn breeds intimate relations. In this course, we will explore the various ways in which intimacy functions as a kind of knowledge about peoples and bodies in relation to one another. Broad questions we will investigate include: How and when do we mark an experience as intimate? Who gets to have certain kinds of intimate experiences, but not others? Where is intimacy permissible and where is it not? What other modes of being in relation can be claimed as intimate? Can fear, shame, and anxiety be counted as felt states of intimacy? On a smaller scale, this will include investigating the reading experience itself as one that generates a kind of intimate knowledge: about ourselves and potentially about other people, too. In turn, we will work through the process of writing as a kind of intimate exchange between ourselves as writers and the texts we read. Speaking in a practical sense, one of main goals will be to improve our reading and writing skills by thinking critically about what writers put on a page and the effects of those choices. 
 
Required Texts, available at Prairie Lights:
The Handmaid’s Tale 978-0385490818
Don’t Let Me Be Lonely 978-1555974077  Winesburg, Ohio 978-0140186550

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Transgressive Literatures
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course will examine literatures—short fiction, novels, essays, drama, and poetry—whose protagonists/speakers/narrators engage in illicit lifestyles to perpetrate various acts of transgression, which, according to Rene Chen of the New York Times, tend to explore divergent behaviors such as:
“incest and other aberrant sexual practices, mutilation, the sprouting of sexual organs in various places on the human body, urban violence and violence against women, drug use, and highly dysfunctional family relationships, and that is based on the premise that knowledge is to be found at the edge of experience and that the body is the site for gaining knowledge.”  
Within this context, we will engage the humane versus the profane, and how likewise dichotomies exist to challenge our historical biases within a culture of evolving paradigms.
 
Course requirements include informal reading responses, two essays, two exams, active class participation, and a final portfolio.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            The Politics of Perception
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Are human beings capable of perceiving the world the way it really is, or are we under the influence of some kind of delusion? And if we are under the influence of some kind of delusion, who—or what—sustains it? God? Government? Language? Technology? Our own minds? Fake news?  Scientists, philosophers, and artists in western culture have been asking these questions for millennia—from Plato’s allegory of the cave to Descartes’s argument from doubt, Kant’s transcendental idealism, Marx’s formulation of ideology, Freud’s postulation of the unconscious, and the host of postmodern thinkers who question the existence of objective truth.  As such, the theme of this course could be called “the politics of perception.” Reading across a range of genres and mediums—including poetry, short stories, novels, and film—we will consider the ways in which texts engage how we perceive. We will consider how the worlds of, and in, fiction intersect with our own, and what factors influence the meaning we make of, and from, them. We will pay special attention to texts that attempt to challenge or even disrupt our everyday perceptions, inviting us to imagine a different kind of world.
 
While our theme will be the politics of perception, this is a general education course designed to introduce students to literary analysis, effective argumentation, and college-level writing. This class will also afford students the opportunity to sharpen a widely-applicable toolkit, which includes the ability to think critically and communicate well-developed ideas in all walks of life.
 
Course requirements include essays, various informal writing assignments, exams, and a final group presentation.
 
Required texts (available at the University Bookstore):  Shelley, Mary. Frankenstein (1831) (Penguin, 978-0141439471)  Dick, Philip K. Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? (Del Rey, 978-0345404473)  Miéville, China. The City & The City (Del Rey/Random House, 978-0345497529)

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            The (Dis-)Enchanted Worlds of Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Required Course Texts: (available at Prairie Lights bookstore, 15 S. Dubuque Street, Iowa City) 
Tim O’Brien, The Things They Carried (Marnier Books) 
Arthur Conan Doyle, A Study in Scarlet (Penguin Classics Edition)
Frederick Douglass, Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave (Library of America Edition)
“The Interpretation of Literature: A University of Iowa Anthology.” ISBN 9781307010893

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Reckoning with Time
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
From sweeping historical epics to the briefest of lyric moments, literature tries to capture the experience of time passing in all sorts of ways. During this course, we’ll look at a wide variety of texts and think about all the strategies they use to imagine, represent, and make sense of the passage of time. Major strands of discussion will include the way stories grapple with the personal history of the individual; the transformative conversation that texts engage in by building off each other and off of the culture at large; and the entrypoint that literature provides to broad historical and political perspectives on the world around us.
Bookstore: Prairie Lights
Book List:
Literature: A Portable Anthology, 4th Edition [Bedford / St. Martin’s Press, ISBN 97841319035341, $46.70] 2017  The Autobiography of Red – Ann Carson [Vintage, ISBN 9780375701290, $15.00] 1999 The Left Hand of Darkness – Ursula LeGuin [Ace Books, 9780441478125, $9.99] 1987 Beloved – Toni Morrison [Vintage, 9781400033416, $16.00] 2004 
(Total: $87.69)

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Modernity and its Discontents: Religion, Secularism, and the Person
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Required Texts, available at the Hawk Shop:




Dickinson, Emily. Final Harvest. Back Bay Books. 978-0316184151.
 
Whitman, Walt. Leaves of Grass. Dover.  978-0486456768
 
Hawthorne, Nathaniel. Nathaniel Hawthorne’s Tales. Norton. 978-0393954265

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            American Humor
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Reading View. Press Alt Shift A for accessibility help.
This course is a survey of American humor that will explore what makes people laugh, how writers use humor to elicit particular responses, and the place of humor in both American literature and popular culture. In the process we will investigate the depth and variety of the American experience. The content of this course includes plays, poems, fiction, non-fiction, short stories, and situational and stand-up comedies. By analyzing humor in American culture we will also be developing and strengthening analytical reading and writing skills.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Should There Be Such a Thing as Literature?
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Required Text, at the Hawk Shop:
Literature: The Human Experience, 12th Edition. Bedford/St. Martin's Press (2016). ISBN 978-4576-9993-1

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Breaking Boundaries: Hybrid and Experimental Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course will be an exploration of literary works that push the limits. Each week, we will examine, in great detail, poems, short stories, and essays that challenge our pre-conceived notions of what literature is, does, and can be. Through student-led discussion, we will interpret these selections stylistically, formally, and contextually. This course will privilege quality over quantity-- although most of the readings are short, they are all intricately crafted and often experimental. The texts will require patience and diligence as we explore them, as well as perceptive and critical eyes when we consider how to respond to them in writing.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            London Past and Present, or the Idea of the City
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Cities capture the literary imagination because they are fascinating spaces of contrast: anonymity and close proximity, pleasure and vice, spectatorship and terror, glamour and destitution, and so much more. In this course, we will explore these and many other themes by virtually walking the streets of London, getting to know the city as a character in its own right in the stories we will read.
