We will explore why London has such a prominent role in English literature, offering our own interpretations of the city, and generating ideas of what urban spaces can tell us about ourselves as individuals and as a society: what we fear, what we desire, what we strive for, and what we suppress. Since London is one of the most written-about cities in literature, it is the perfect case-study for developing our interpretative and analytical skills, offering us the chance to look at the city from multiple perspectives.
Course Texts, from Prairie Lights:
Charles Dickens, A Tale of Two Cities. Penguin Classics. ISBN: 978-0141439600
Winifred Watson, Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day. Persephone Books. ISBN: 978-0141439600
Neil Gaiman, Neverwhere (Author’s Preferred Text). William Morrow. ISBN: 9780062459084
Eliza Haywood, Fantomina, Broadview Press. ISBN: 978-1551115245

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Living Spaces
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The topic of this course, “Living Spaces,” encourages students to think critically about their environments, both natural and created, by reading literary works related to issues such as housing, social reform, and environmentalist fiction. Students will complete the assigned reading, participate in in-depth discussions in class, and write papers and informal writing assignments. In addition to the three required course texts, students will read short stories, poems, and excerpts that may be provided electronically or via handouts.
Required texts, available at the Hawk Shop:
Louisa May Alcott/Work: A Story of Experience [978-0140390919]
Nathaniel Hawthorne / The House of the Seven Gables (Norton Critical Edition) [978-0393924763]
Matthew Desmond / Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City [978-0553447453]

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Fragmenting Bodies of/in Literature from WWI to Present
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
We open it at the spine, examine its body, and then move to the appendix. Thankfully, we are not in surgery; we are reading. Nevertheless, texts come to us, often, in fragments, “and all parts / spine / into spine,” as Lorine Niedecker suggests in “Traces of Living Things.”
As a body and addressing the body, literatures in the twentieth and twenty-first centuries have grappled with extraordinary shifts in the way we understand and experience bodies—both our own and the “othered” body. Historically, World War I churned up an undercurrent of fragmentation, where the horrors of warfare filtered back into societal consciousness. Writers and poets addressed the broken body not only in subject but also in literary technique. From there, the body faced further fragmentation in an era filled with issues related to the rights, representations, and reconceptualization of the body. Writers and poets continued to challenge the boundaries, conventions, and rules that governed and affected different bodies, utilizing the book and its body as a means for experimentation.
This course will explore the body of text and the body in text, examining the ways in which writers have historically engaged with material and physical representation, as well as how they have challenged notions of agency, performance, unity, and autonomy. Through historical relationships, avant-garde poetics, and theoretical concepts like assemblage, we will consider the body as material, technique, and subject. Ultimately, we will consider how literature has imagined or projected the body as a response to social or political conditions.  
 Required Texts, at Prairie Lights Bookstore:

Margaret Atwood, The Handmaid’s Tale [Anchor/Doubleday, ISBN 978-0385490818] $15.95
Claudia Rankine, Don’t Let Me Be Lonely [Graywolf Press, ISBN 978-1-55597-407-7] $16
Anne Carson, Antigonick [New Directions, ISBN 9780811222938] $11.95

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Otherness and Community
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In this course, we will be exploring literature through the theme of "Otherness and Community." Each of the works we will discuss deals with people who are "different." Our discussions will address to what extent difference enables or hinders community. We will also discuss the ways in which literature allows us to connect to those who are similar to and those who are different from ourselves.
Books, from Prairie Lights:
Austen, Jane. Pride and Prejudice. Norton, 4th Edition. ISBN  0393976041  
Shakespeare, William. Twelfth Night. Folger Shakespeare Library (2005) ISBN  0743484967 
Card, Orson Scott. Enders Game. Tom Doherty Associates (1994) ISBN 9780812550702 
Wilson, G Willow. Ms Marvel. Marvel (2014) ISBN 078519021X 
Students should also plan to print several readings that are available online and will be posted to ICON.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            The Sampler Platter: A Literary Tasting Course
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Fact: Nearly 130,000,000 books rest on bookshelves, armrests, and bedside tables worldwide. Google it. 
It’s impossible to read all the books, but it is possible to taste a few popular genres. Like the sampler platter appetizer at any good restaurant, this class has something for everyone: fantasy, dystopia, historical fiction, mystery, and non-fiction memoir. We’ll read from multiple formal genres (drama, novels, short stories, poems, essays) across these thematic genres. We’ll dip our texts in a variety of analytical sauces—personal response, comparative analysis, historical context, generic tropes—in the service of closely reading the text. We’ll write about our reactions to the readings often and discuss them in class even more. We’ll play with our food, spill it on our shirts, and sometimes spit it into our napkins. At the end of the semester, you will take your expanded palate on a journey to find the genre with which you most connect through reviewing a book of your own choice.
Vigilant attendance and active presence in the class are a must, or you’ll miss the eleven pop quizzes interspersed throughout the semester. Sharpen a pencil and get out some Post-Its, because you’ll have a daily reading task to bring in for each discussion. You’ll write a few informal reading responses, two analytical essays, a final book review, and compile a final portfolio of your writing. Bon appétit!
 
Required Texts, Available at Prairie Lights Bookstore
Margaret Atwood, The Handmaid’s Tale  978-0385490818
Toni Morrison, Song of Solomon 978-1400033423
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, A Study in Scarlet 978-0140439083
William Shakespeare, A Midsummer Night’s Dream 978-0451526960
Joy Harjo, Crazy Brave  978-0393345438If you are not a member of the University of Iowa Honors Program, you may contact the course instructor in order to request permission to enroll.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Literature and the Fantastic
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Literature has a surprising history of using the impossible or imagined to help its readers understand those concerns most pressing in the real world. Whether it is science fiction imagining inhumane technological futures, fantasy which challenges reductive views of the world, or horror as a means to explore psychological trauma, these genres imagine alternatives to realism as a means to find and articulate meaning. As a class we will explore how these expressions emerge in graphic novels, film, poetry, short stories and novels. Over the course of the class we will produce two mini-essays which will each be expanded into more substantial 5-6 page papers. In lieu of a final we will have semi-regular quizzes.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Voices from the Margins: Writing on Queerness, Race, Class, and More
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This class will explore a host of voices from the margins, ranging from Beyoncé’s Lemonade to the story of a nerdy Dominican kid growing up in New Jersey. Through a host of mediums including the graphic novel, memoir, poetry, literary nonfiction, visual art, and more, we will ask how is otherness conveyed in literature? What can writing do to erase (or reinforce) divides between communities? How can writing both replicate and transcend social constructions we see in the world around us? What do you bring, as a reader, to these conversations? Among our potential guides for this term: Alison Bechdel, Junot Díaz, Jamaica Kincaid, Claudia Rankine, Marguerite Duras, Eula Biss, James Baldwin, Walt Whitman, Natasha Trethewey, Theresa Hak Kyung Cha, and Jenny Zhang.
 
Book list (available at Prairie Lights):
Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic, Alison Bechdel (2006) (Mariner, ISBN 978-0618871711) The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao, Junot Díaz (2008) (Riverhead, ISBN 978-1594483295) A Small Place, Jamaica Kincaid (1988) (Farrar, Straus, & Giroux, ISBN 978-0374527075) Citizen: An American Lyric, Claudia Rankine (2014) (Graywolf, ISBN 978-1555976903)
(supplemented by additional readings on ICON)

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Stories that Save Us: Narrative and the Art of Survival
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
"We tell ourselves stories in order to live.” This is the very first line of the very last reading of our semester, and it also functions as the thesis statement for the course. You may ask, “Why would you drop this massive spoiler just as we’re setting out? Now we all know how it ends.” But, as with any good thesis statement, this one means little unless it can be prodded, bent, stretched, and otherwise explored through a multitude of lenses. Thus, while we may know why, ultimately, we tell stories, we still have much to ask ourselves: Who is telling these stories? What choices are they making in the telling? What happens when parts of a story are silenced, or fragmented, or twisted, or lost? What do stories recover? Do stories merely help us survive, or can they change the course of our lives, of others’ lives? For better? For worse? Throughout the semester we will dig deeper into the art of narrative to find the stories that change us.
Coursework will involve daily participation in class discussions, reading quizzes, short responses, two papers, and a short media project

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Tyranny, Oppression, and Resistance
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The United States prides itself on being a free and open society, a “beacon of freedom for all the peoples of the Earth” to quote president Ronald Reagan. In order to be a such a society, it is imperative to study those things which threaten such ideals and the work that is required in order to maintain them. Tyranny and oppression can vary in scope from the personal to the whole of society and all levels in between. The shining beacon casts many shadows, and in those shadows tyranny is nurtured and oppression thrives. Whatever the scope of these ills, it is necessary to learn to recognize them in order to combat them. And in order to combat them, it is important to understand the language of resistance.
To better understand systems of oppression and tyranny, and how resistance operates within and around them, we will engage with several literary works exploring several types of oppression, tyranny, and resistance. One of our goals is to read these texts with an aim at understanding how they frame these subjects, their stances, and the language they employ. We will read two novels in this class: Margaret Atwood’s The Handmaid’s Tale and Octavia Butler’s Kindred which explore, among other things, racial and gender oppression. We will also read Alison Bechdel’s graphic memoir Fun Home, about coming to terms with her father’s life in the closet and the formation of her own lesbian identity, and Claudia Rankine’s Citizen, which reflects on present issues surrounding the discourses of race in America.
We will also read other texts provided through ICON including poetry by Natasha Trethewey, short stories by Nathaniel Hawthorne and Ursela K. LeGuin, Lorraine Hansberry’s A Raisin in the Sun, and other texts. This course will feature a midterm and two papers, as well as other assignments.
 
Margaret Atwood, The Handmaid’s Tale (1985, Doubleday/ISBN 978-0385490818) - $15.95
Octavia Butler, Kindred (1979, Beacon/ISBN 978-0807083697) - $16.00
Claudia Rankine, Citizen: An American Lyric (2014, Graywolf/ISBN 978-1555976903) - $20
Alison Bechdel, Fun Home: A Family Tragicomic (2004, Mariner/ISBN 978-0618871711) - $15.99

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Writing in the Apocalypse
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Writing in the Apocalypse
This is a course about life after the apocalypse –  its representation in literature as well as its religious underpinning, contemporary theorization, and political value. Over the course of the semester, we will question the plurality of apocalypses: their multiple locations, velocities, temporalities, and splatter radiuses. We will read accounts of life after modern apocalypses – slavery and Jim Crow, WWII and the Holocaust, colonialism and environmental collapse, 9/11 and the War on Terror – and ask how life can continue during the end times. Our texts will cover the range of forms that apocalypse takes, from personal to global, momentary to infinite. As a central practice, we will attend to feminist, queer, and critical race studies. And by the close of our class we will hopefully come to better understand the lasting appeal of the end—the end of history, suffering, and knowledge. 
Texts
Song of Solomon, by Toni Morrison
Endgame, by Samuel Beckett
My Atonia, by Willa Cather 
Don't Let Me Be Lonely, by Claudia Rankine
 
Bookstore
Prairie Lights

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Imagining Community
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
When we read, several factors—gender, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, geographical origins, attitudes toward the environment, etc.—influence our interpretation of texts. The texts, too, come from a specific moment in history, which, in addition to the factors above, influenced the author. We (readers and writers) also belong to several different communities, which influences the way we read texts and the way writers produce texts. In this class, we will explore how these social, cultural, and historical dynamics not only influence the reading and writing of texts, but also how they shape ideas of community. By the end of the class, we hope to be stronger, more confident readers who have developed our interpretive skills and our ability to communicate ideas about texts both verbally and in more formal arguments. Moreover, we hope to establish habits that will make us life-long readers who can respond intelligently and critically to texts of all kinds. To that end, we will be reading short stories, poems, nonfiction, novels, and one short play. Students should be prepared to engage texts rigorously and to come to class ready to participate actively in classroom discussion.
Course requirements include several short reading responses, one formal essay, and three quizzes.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Gender Outlaws: Monstrous Mothers, Queer Prophets, Wolves, and Witches
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Gender Outlaws: Monstrous Mothers, Queer Prophets, Wolves and Witches
 In this class, we’ll encounter characters who refuse to conform to traditional gender roles. These characters call into question societal assumptions about gender identity and even threaten to overturn their communities’ firmly held beliefs. Some of these characters exist on the margins and even the outside of the communal project. We will also see how many of these characters continue to transgress, however, by forcing their way back in, altering their communities as they do so. We’ll read a novel, as well as multiple short stories, poems, and plays from various time periods as we explore some of the radical ways in which gender is used to provoke self-questioning and communal-restructuring.
 
Required texts (available at the University Book Store):
 
Dracula – Bram Stoker, Norton Critical, ISBN 9780393970128
 
Norton Introduction to Literature, Shorter 12th Edition, Mays, Kelly J., ed., Norton ISBN 978-0-393-93892-0
 
Natasha Trethewey, Native Guard, Mariner, ISBN 978-0618872657
 
Angels in America– Tony Kushner (Parts 1 & 2) [Theatre Communications Group, ISBN 9781559362313, $16.95]

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Dystopian Futures
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Within this section of Interpretation of Literature, we will investigate science fiction's cultural commentary on technology, the environment, gender, race, and more. While focused on works of science fiction, we will also step outside the genre to consider the cultural commentary within many poems and short stories. All stories encountered in this course will force readers to think critically about the future of humankind.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            Literature Gone Mad
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In this course, students will analyze literature through the lens of mad studies, an interdisciplinary discourse that seeks to restructure psychiatric models of mental illness by attending to lived experiences of neurodiversity, redefine definitions of sanity and madness, and interrogate the power dynamics surrounding madness. Through readings posted to ICON, students will be introduced to mad studies (and disability studies more broadly) and will consider how it might inform their readings of canonical and non-canonical literary works—both personal accounts and fictional representations of mental illness—as well as how it might reframe their understanding of madness. Together, we’ll attack the stigma surrounding mental illness and challenge its pathologization. Coursework will include reading responses, regular reading quizzes, two short papers, and a group project.

name: The Interpretation of Literature                                            The End of the World as We Know It
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Reading opens the door to strange new worlds, and reading opens strange new doors to our own world. This semester, we will be working with characters whose worlds have irrevocably shifted, due to apocalyptic forces, the zombie invasion, hyper-commercialized social networking, magical happenings and more. Our readings will come from multiple literary genres, including short stories, plays, poems, and three novels: Gary Shteyngart’s Super Sad True Love Story, Colson Whitehead’s Zone One, and Don DeLillo’s White Noise. As we read, we will consider how characters’ identities shift in response to trauma and the pressures of heroism, how they work to interpret the new worlds they inhabit, and what these new worlds teach us about our own.
In this course, we will focus on the act of interpretation, using and refining our skills of reading, speaking, and writing to respond critically and sensitively to literary texts. We will consider a web of relations between the text, ourselves as readers, and the historical, social, political, and cultural worlds in which both texts and readers reside. Students must come prepared to rigorously and imaginatively engage with the class material, seeing themselves as critical readers and members of a community of inquirers. Course requirements include active participation, various informal writings in the form of a commonplace book, a series of quizzes, two formal essays, and a final exam.

name: The Interpretation of Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
View introduction video 

Required Texts:
The Warden, Anthony Trollope (Penguin Classics, 978-0140432145)
O Pioneers!, Willa Cather (Oxford World's Classics, 978-0192832160)
Captain America, vol. 1 (Marvel Comics, digital purchase from comicstore.marvel.com full title: Captain America Comics 1941-1950 #1)
Please note: There will be two mandatory online class meetings, the first on Tuesday, September 19th at 6:30pm, and the second on Tuesday, October 17th at 6:30pm. Students enrolled in this section are required to be available for these meetings. This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Literature and Sexualities                                            Queer Americans
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In 2015, the U.S. Supreme Court granted same-sex couples the right to marry in Obergefell v. Hodges. The decision was seen by many as the pinnacle of a decades-long struggle for LGBT rights, beginning with the Stonewall riots in 1969. But as the recent shooting at a gay bar in Orlando has indicated, the progression of what many would call equal rights for LGBT people in the United States has not exactly been linear. In this course, we will look at a range of texts that depict the LGBT experience in the United States, and we’ll also consider how queer-identified writers explore queerness in their texts. Broadly speaking, this class will ask you to engage in different ways of reading, including the individual reader’s experience of the text, the features of the text itself, and the text’s place in larger historical, social, political, and cultural contexts. In writing assignments and in class discussion, we will respond critically, sensitively, and articulately to literature.
Required Texts, available at Prairie Lights:
Lunch Poems by Frank O’Hara (ISBN: 9780872860353)
Fun Home by Alison Bechdel (ISBN: 9780618871711)
Passing by Nella Larsen (ISBN: 9780393979169)
Go Tell It on the Mountain by James Baldwin (ISBN: 9780375701870)
Middlesex by Jeffrey Eugenides (ISBN: 9780312427733).

name: Sex & Popular Culture in the Postwar US
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course offers a critical and historical survey of the representation of human sexuality within American popular culture—including literature, cinema, television, music, comics, and fashion—from the end of World War II to the present. The class persistently investigates an apparent contradiction: why and how have acts and desires typically valued as highly personal and private (our "sex lives") been consistently made available to a mass public through popular, commercial media in modern America? Emphasizing the intertwined fascination with heterosexuality and homosexuality in mass media since the publication of the infamous Kinsey Reports just after WWII, this class considers popular responses to and representations of (among other events): the contradictory sexual discourses of the Cold War era, the “sexual revolution” and the rise of the women’s liberation movement, gay liberation and “queer” activism, and recent manifestations of “post-feminist” ideologies.  Readings for the course include a wide range of primary materials in various genres (fiction, drama, memoir, journalism, etc.) as well as retrospective historical and cultural studies. Students are required to attend two weekly (heavily illustrated) lectures by the course instructor and one weekly discussion section led by a teaching assistant. Course requirements include a series of short essays and response papers, a midterm and final exam, and regular attendance and participation (in discussion sections).

name: Foundations of the English Major
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is an introduction to the history, theory, and practice of English as a discipline.   It teaches four central aspects of literary study:  1) the techniques of literary criticism, including close reading and the analysis of form and genre; 2) insight into literary and critical theory, and familiarity with debates over interpretation that have shaped the reading of literature and have transformed English as a field; 3) the periods of literary history, such as Medieval, Early Modern, Modern, Postcolonial, etc., that constitute the English major at the University of Iowa; and 4) knowledge of the research and writing skills that are essential to the practice of literary criticism.

name: Reading and Writing About the Novel                                            Selected Global Fiction
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The class will study selected novels from the last part of the twentieth century and the early part of the twenty-first.  Each of the novels centers on two or more cities, areas, countries, or cultures, examining the connections between them.  History is shown to be public and private; public events and crises affect individual lives.

Does the opposite happen?  Do the protagonists grow to moral and intellectual awareness and in the process begin to change the world?
The novels will be studied in terms of form, structure and characterization. Can the novel form deal with the whole world and with complex issues or does it seek help from other art forms?  If so, how do the novels bring in other art forms?
Students will be expected to participate in class discussions but the final grade will be on the basis of three essays of six pages each or a paper of eighteen pages.  Essays and papers will be judged on the basis of quality of thought, creativity of  ideas, and clarity in the writing and in the interpretation of the chosen prompt.
Students may miss up to three classes without explanation.
Novels:
Alex La Guma, A Walk in the Night
Bessie Head, MARU
Margaret Mascarenhas (United States/India), SKIN
H.M. Naqvi (Pakistan), Home Boy, Random House
Suchen Christine Lim, The River’s Song
Ishmael Reed (United States), Flight to Canada

name: Reading and Writing About Poetry                                            Words that Matter
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
“Poetry is a break for freedom. In a sense all poems are good; all poems are an emblem of courage and the attempt to say the unsayable; but only a few are able to speak to something universal yet personal and distinct at the same time; to create a door through which others can walk into what previously seemed unobtainable realms, in the passage of a few short lines.” David Whyte
This course explores the power and the relevance of contemporary poetry. We ask, “What can a poem do in the world?” and the answers may surprise you. Working with Adrienne Rich’s Poetry and Commitment and Muriel Rukeyser’s The Life of Poetry, we examine such themes as the politics of difference, issues of gender, the historical self, the construction of race and the crisis of the environment. This course argues for the necessity of poetry in a complicated and fractured world. Course requirements will include a response journal, a series of take home quizzes and writing assignments and active and engaged participation in class discussions.

name: Reading and Writing About Short Stories
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course focuses on how we interpret short fiction and how we write critical essays about it. We will study the evolution of the short story by reading examples of the genre by US and international authors from the last two centuries. We will explore how each story’s meaning is shaped by formal elements such as narration, plot, setting, characterization, dialogue, and style. The other primary goal of the course is to improve students’ critical writing. We will devote significant time to the process of writing successful critical essays, from brainstorming a topic to crafting a thesis statement to finding and citing critical sources to structuring an argument. Students should finish the course with a deeper understanding of the short story as a genre and improved abilities as critical writers.
Coursework includes class participation, a reading journal with weekly postings, and two 5-page papers that go through a draft and revision process.
Required text:
Ann Charters (ed.), The Story and Its Writer: An Introduction to Short Fiction, 9th edition (2015), ISBN 978-1457664618.

name: Reading and Writing About Drama                                            Classic Plays on Contemporary Stages
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Drama is the only form of literature written mainly for performance. We will read eight plays, treating them as texts made for use in the theatre by writers, actors, directors, designers, and audiences. We will also see and hear how these plays have been reused, restaged, and remade in contemporary productions and adaptations.
Our study of these plays and productions will encompass a variety of media, including printed and digital texts, photographs, films and videos, and music. Scholarly essays and reviews will inform our discussions and provide you with models for the critical writing you will practice in a series of informal and formal assignments.
Writing assignments will include two 6-page papers, a performance review, and weekly reading journal entries.
Readings include:

Carson, Anne. Antigonick (Sophokles). Translated  by Anne Carson. Illustrated by Bianca Stone. New York: New Directions, 2012. ISBN 978-0-8112-1957-0
Lorca, Federico Garcia. Yerma. In Three Plays. Translated by Michael Dewell and Carmen Zapata. New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1993. ISBN 978-0374523329
McCraney, Tarell Alvin. In the Red and Brown Water. In The Brother/Sister Plays. New York: Theatre Communications Group, 2010. ISBN 978-1-55936-349-5-51695

name: Foundations of Creative Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This intensive multi-genre seminar workshop will introduce new majors to the art of creative writing. We will concentrate on issues of craft as we explore essential elements of poetry, fiction, and nonfiction.

name: Literary Readings Attendance
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This flexibly-scheduled course introduces students to Iowa City’s vibrant literary scene and provides a learning experience based on the cutting-edge knowledge available from focused attendance at live readings given by creative and scholarly writers. It also models the fusion of reading and writing that is central to the major in English. The course will meet twice in a regular classroom setting, on Wednesday, August 23, 2017 from 11:30am-12:20pm and Wednesday, December 6, 2017 from 11:30am-12:20pm; alternate times will be arranged for students who have scheduling conflicts. During the rest of the semester, students attend 10 talks or readings, choosing from a regularly updated calendar that will be available throughout the semester. Full details about the course can be found on its ICON site. This course is graded S/U.

name: English at Work
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Your friends and parents have been asking for years: what on earth are you going to do with an English degree? And let’s be honest: you’re not entirely sure either! In this class, we will be joining forces with staff from the Pomerantz Career Center to find answers to these questions. Over the course of the semester you will learn why the knowledge and skills you gain as an English major are in demand among a wide variety of employers. In the process, we will guide you through important steps you can take as a student to translate your ambitions into reality.

name: Modern Fiction
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course is a jargon-free introduction to the 20th-century novel. FORMAL lectures on what made such fiction new and different – by examining post-war, post-imperial, post-realist, multicultural, and global tendencies; and by attending both to the practice of novel writing and to theoretical debates among novelists – will offer students ideas about how to read people like Henry James, Gertrude Stein, and Ernest Hemingway: how, in other words, to enjoy their weird experiments; how to evaluate them as well. The lectures, moreover, will suggest ways to understand and appreciate the more difficult forms of modern fiction. Grades are based on midterm and final examinations. They are also based on attendance.
Required texts:
Samuel Beckett, Murphy   978-0-8021-4445-4
Nadine Gordimer, July’s People       0-14-006-140-1
Ernest Hemingway, In Our Time      0-684-82276-8     
Henry James, The Portrait of a Lady              0-14-144-126-9
James Joyce, Dubliners     0-14-004222-9
Marcel Proust, Swann’s Way             0-14-243796-4
Jean Rhys, Wide Sargasso Sea         0-393-30880-4
Salman Rushdie, Midnight’s Children           0-14-013270-8
David Sedaris, Barrel Fever              0-316-77942-3
Gertrude Stein, Three Lives                0-312-18356-9
Evelyn Waugh, Decline and Fall     0-316-92607-8
Virginia Woolf, Mrs. Dalloway         0-15-662870-8

name: Literature, Culture, and Women                                            Women Writers of the Beat Movement
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. AREA: Literary Theory and Interdisciplinary Studies. PERIOD: 20th/21st century literature for Fall 2017.
In a June 1959 Playboy article titled, “The Origins of the Beat Generation,” Jack Kerouac defined the modern Beats as wise men of few words, accompanied by women of fewer, writing: “The ‘cool’ (hipster) today is your bearded laconic sage, or schlerm, before a hardly touched beer in a beatnik dive, whose speech is low and unfriendly, whose girls say nothing and wear black.” Traditionally, critics have understood the position of women within the Beat community as peripheral, marking the literary “boy gang” of writers as a self-sustaining homosocial artistic community. For many years, with the notable exception of Diane di Prima, few women writers gained recognition as part of this literary movement, but in recent decades, memoirs by Beat women have spurred feminist recovery efforts to set the record straight. In this course, we will consider the place of these women writers within the Beat canon. We will first begin the semester by defining “Beat” together, focusing on work by foundational Beat writers Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg, and William S. Burroughs. Next, we will turn to memoirs written by the women of the Beat Generation to consider the role of this genre within reconstructions of the Beat canon. Finally, we will examine fiction and poetry by these women writers, thinking about how our definitions of “Beat” change by broadening the term to encompass these works, as well as drawing connections between these writers’ aesthetics and stories.

name: Selected British Authors Before 1900                                            William Wordsworth
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Author of some of the best-loved poems in English, the Romantic poet William Wordsworth (1770-1850) became a true literary celebrity in his day, drawing both fawning adulation and some of the most vicious reviews imaginable. An unfaithful lover or a devoted husband and father, a radical revolutionary who became a Victorian conservative, a nature poet and early advocate for the environment, a bard of liberty or of the egotistical sublime: who was Wordsworth? The answers today are almost as varied as during his lifetime.
In this class we will read a range of Wordsworth’s poetry – from Lyrical Ballads (1798), the volume that inspired a generation of Romantic poets, to the great middle works and the poem he crafted and taunted readers with for the last 50 years of his life, the one that would tie his poetry together and reveal what they had kept shrouded, which he referred to as the “poem on the growth of my mind” and which was published after his death as The Prelude. We’ll also read portions of Juliet Barker’s award-winning biography of Wordsworth, contemporary reviews by his original readers, and controversial criticism from our own day. We’ll explore topics inspired by his poems and their context in his life and times – childhood, education, the French Revolution, Nature, religion, sexuality – all the while keeping in mind how those topics relate to the great story Wordsworth was working on behind the scenes: not heroic adventure or the fall from Eden, but the story The Prelude tells, which he considered of epic proportions, of the growth of a poet’s mind.
 
Reading List:
Wordsworth & Coleridge, Lyrical Ballads: 1798 and 1802, Oxford ISBN-13: 978-0199601967
Stephen Gill, ed. William Wordsworth: The Major Works, including The Prelude, (Oxford World’s Classics) ISBN-13: 978-0199536863

name: Selected British Authors After 1900                                            Joyce and Beckett
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: James Joyce was an exceptional influence on all twentieth-century writers, but especially on fellow Irishman Samuel Beckett, who began writing after meeting Joyce at the age of 22 in Paris.This course will focus on the modernist fiction and drama of both writers, exploring how their work helped to define what it means to be “modern.” Readings from Joyce will include: Portrait of an Artist, Dubliners, Ulysses, and selections from Finnegans Wake. From Becket: Murphy, Watt, Waiting for Godot, Endgame, Krapp’s Last Tape, Nott I, and selections from his radio drama. Requirements will include one oral presentation and two medium-size seminar papers.

name: Topics in Modern British Lit After 1900                                            Media and Modernism
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course will explore how new media contributed to the development of a distinctly modern literature. Together, we will pursue the following lines of inquiry: How did the typewriter, phonograph, telephone, cinema, and radio remediate while also actively reshaping narrative, dramatic, and poetic form? How did these technologies reorganize the human sensorium and reconfigure human subjectivity? How can “British” modernist writers (broadly defined) be read as placing questions of technology and mediation in conversation with questions of gender, race, sexuality, and national identity? Students will be introduced to major works in media theory through excerpts made available on ICON. By considering aspects of the development of media technologies in relation to nineteenth- and twentieth-century works by Bram Stoker, Henry James, T. S. Eliot, Sophie Treadwell, Virginia Woolf, Samuel Beckett, and others, we will tease out the reciprocal relationship between technological innovation and literary production, cultivating a deeper appreciation for the intermediality of our technological modernity.
 
Course readings include:

Bram Stoker, Dracula (Oxford World’s Classics, 2011). 978-0-1900-56409-5.
Henry James, The Turn of the Screw & In the Cage (Modern Library Classics, 2001). 978-0-375-75740-2.
T. S. Eliot, The Waste Land, Norton Critical Editions (Norton, 2000). 978-0-393-97499-7.
Sophie Treadwell, Machinal (Royal National Theatre, 1995). 978-1-854-59211-8.
Virginia Woolf, Between the Acts (Annotated) (Harvest Books, 2008). 978-0-156-03473-9.
Samuel Beckett, Three Novels: Molloy, Malone Dies, The Unnamable (Grove Press, 2009). 978-0-8021-4447-8.

name: Victorian Literature                                            Telling Tales: Short Stories from Great Britain and Ireland
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Rooted in an ancient oral tradition but coming of age within an increasingly complex and extensive empire, literary short stories from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland flourished during the nineteenth century. This flexible genre offered broad appeal as it addressed an array of compelling issues in an economical and entertaining form. Exploring a variety of theoretical perspectives and cultural contexts, we will map the fascinating development of British and Irish short stories—from insightful folk tales and fairy legends to stark and disenchanted fictions of modern life. Cultural, social, and political connections (and disconnections) within the “United Kingdom” will remain central as we focus on what stories reveal about individuals and nations.
Requirements include active class discussion, short reading responses, a presentation, one longer essay, and a final exam.
Required texts:
Dunn, Douglas (ed.). The Oxford Book of Scottish Short Stories. Oxford UP, 2009. ISBN-13: 978-0199556540 ISBN-10: 0199556547Byatt, A.S., editor. The Oxford Book of English Short Stories. Oxford UP, 2008.  ISBN-10:0199561605 ISBN-13: 978-0199561605
Trevor, William (ed.). The Oxford Book of Irish Short Stories. Oxford UP, 2010.  ISBN-13: 978-0199583140 ISBN-10: 0199583145
MLA HANDBOOK. 8th ed. MLA, 2016.  ISBN-13: 978-1603292627 ISBN-10: 1603292624

name: Selected American Authors Before 1900                                            Emily Dickinson and Walt Whitman
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course counts for the American Literature and Culture area requirement and for the Eighteenth- and/or Nineteenth-Century historical period.
We will focus on the work of the two major American poets of the nineteenth century, two of the most innovative and original poets ever to have written in the English language. Significantly, neither one was recognized as a major poet by the reading public during his or her own lifetime, though Whitman had a small but very devoted following. We will be coming at their poetry from a number of angles: biographical, cultural, aesthetic, historical. We will talk about ways that their poetry has come to influence several generations of American poets who followed them. We'll weave in and out of their work, discussing ways they responded to key nineteenth-century events (like the Civil War, developing technology, changing notions of science and religion, women's rights movements) and ways they challenged orthodox notions of writing poetry, of configuring gender, and of projecting America's future. We'll move back and forth between Whitman and Dickinson, looking for places where the work of one engages the work of the other and initiates a dialogue, a dialogue into which we will learn to insert ourselves.  We will also spend some time in the University Library’s Special Collections, where we have an extraordinary collection of first editions of Whitman’s work and early editions of Dickinson’s poems.
This will be a class in which discussion of the poetry is the central activity.  Students will memorize poems by both Dickinson and Whitman.  There will be quizzes on the biographical reading and a final examination in which students will write short essays comparing passages by both poets.  Students will write two essays on poems by Whitman and Dickinson, informed by our discussions and by the biographical readings.
Texts (will be available at Prairie Lights Bookstore):

Emily Dickinson, The Complete Poems of Emily Dickinson, edited by Thomas H. Johnson (Little, Brown) ISBN-10: 0316184136 ISBN-13: 978-0316184137
Walt Whitman, Poetry and Prose, edited by Justin Kaplan (Library of America) ISBN-10: 1883011353 ISBN-13: 978-1883011352
Lyndall Gordon, Lives Like Loaded Guns: Emily Dickinson and Her Family’s Feuds (Penguin) ISBN-10: 0143119141 ISBN-13: 978-0143119142
David Reynolds, Walt Whitman's America (Random House) ISBN-10: 0679767096 ISBN-13: 978-0679767091

name: Selected American Authors After 1900                                            Toni Morrison
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
As an African American writer who has won a Nobel Prize, Toni Morrison occupies a rare position.  Nevertheless, her impact on late 20th century American literature has been incompletely grasped.  In this class, we will consider the Toni Morrison effect via three distinct, yet related explorations.  First, we will look at how the fictional works that she published between 1970 and 1992 showed a conversation between black novelists and mainstream movements like feminism, postmodernism, and transnationalism.  Second, we will consider how she and her works—both fiction and nonfiction—prompted a charged debate about blackness and American citizenship.  Finally, we will analyze her roles as an editor, an instructor, and a public intellectual to determine her impact on the teaching of literature in American higher education.
 
Texts
Toni Morrison, The Bluest Eye (1970)                                                
Toni Cade Bambara, Gorilla, My Love (1972)                                            
Toni Morrison, Sula (1973)                                                                 
Leon Forrest, There Is A Tree More Ancient Than Eden (1973)      
Gayl Jones, Corregidora (1975)                                                    
Toni Morrison, Song of Solomon (1977)                                             
Toni Morrison, Tar Baby (1981)                                                         
Toni Morrison, Beloved (1987)                                                           
Toni Morrison, Jazz (1992)

name: Selected African American Authors                                            August Wilson and Suzan-Lori Parks
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
While August Wilson’s dramas cannot be termed “kitchen sink realism,” they—in many significant ways—are worlds separated from Suzan-Lori Parks’ experimental productions.  These artists reflect the twin engines of post-Brown v. Board black theater as the older extends the efforts of Lorraine Hansberry and the younger refines the strategies of Adrienne Kennedy.  Notwithstanding the differences in their creative works, these two playwrights ruled the last two decades of the 20th century with a thoroughness that is unprecedented in black theater history.  The Black Arts Movement may have propelled African American drama to widespread mainstream recognition; however, the string of Pulitzers and New York Drama Critics Circle Awards garnered by Wilson and Parks marks an unmatched degree of acclaim.  Gauging their impact on American society between the presidencies of Ronald Reagan and George H.W. Bush, this course will study Wilson’s entire oeuvre and all of Parks’ dramatic work up until 2006.
Texts
Suzan-Lori Parks               
Red Letter Plays
The America Play and Other Works
Topdog/Underdog      
Venus 
 
August Wilson
Jitney
Three Plays    
The Piano Lesson
Two Trains Running
Seven Guitars 
King Hedley II
Gem of the Ocean
Radio Golf

name: Topics in Culture and Identity                                            Stories about HIV/AIDS
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. AREA: Transnational Literature and Postcolonial Studies. PERIOD: 20th/21st-Century Literature for Fall 2017.
Ever since the first media reports about a then still unknown disease began to circulate in the 1980s, HIV/AIDS has captured the imagination of writers and filmmakers. Not only has the illness redefined our understanding of gender and sexuality but—as a sexually transmitted disease—HIV/AIDS has also required us to examine cultural taboos and stigmas. Short stories and novels, feature films and documentaries can help us better comprehend the psychological, cultural, political and historical dimensions of a pandemic that continues to influence life in the twenty-first century.
In this class, we will focus on how African writers and directors have imaginatively engaged with a medical disease such as HIV/AIDS. To what extent do their stories expose and manipulate the stigma and prejudice associated with a sexually transmitted disease? What populations appear especially vulnerable to the disease and its social and economic consequences? How are local communities and governmental institutions involved in shaping responses to HIV/AIDS? How is a medical disease metaphorically appropriated to serve as a general symbol for the challenges of modern life? While this class emphasizes African stories about HIV/AIDS, we will also have an opportunity to reflect on the situation of HIV-positive populations in the United States and engage in a dialogue with people living with the disease.
Course requirements include regular attendance and active participation, a portfolio with responses to the assigned materials, one short paper and a final (critical or creative) project. Creative writing majors welcome.
Texts (available at the Iowa Hawk Shop):
Kgebetli Moele. The Book of the Dead. Cape Town 2009. ISBN-13: 978-0795702884
Phaswane Mpe. Welcome to Our Hillbrow. Pietermaritzburg 2001. ISBN-13: 978-0821419625
Doreen Baingana. Tropical Fish. Cape Town 2005. ISBN-13: 978-0767925105
Liz Walker, Graeme Reid and Morna Cornell. Waiting to Happen: HIV/AIDS in South Africa. Cape Town 2004. ASIN: B01K0V2FZ6
Susan Sontag, Illness as Metaphor and AIDS and Its Metaphors. New York 1990. ISBN-13: 978-0312420130
Films:
Simon and I.  Dir. Beverley Palesa Ditsie and Nick Newman. South Africa 2002.
Life above all. Dir. Oliver Schmitz. South Africa 2011.

name: Book Design for Publishing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Students learn how to design and produce books using Adobe InDesign and other applications in the Adobe Creative Suite. Readings, discussions, in-class critiques, and assignments focus on evaluating and choosing typefaces, book typography, page layout and design, handling image files, and the preparation of materials for print production. Introductory assignments are followed by an individual book design and production project that reflects each student’s particular interest in the field of literary publishing. An introduction to book design history, to historical and contemporary printing methods, and to book design as a career in contemporary publishing, as well as an archival visit to UI Special Collections are part of the course.

name: Topics in Poetry and Poetics                                            The Poetics of Documenting History
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. AREA: Literary Theory and Interdisciplinary Studies. PERIOD: 20th/21st century literature for Fall 2017.
We live in a time in which the poetics of documentary are always at work: witness the importance of the cell phone camera in the documentation of recent events in the struggle for civil and environmental rights across the nation. Claudia Rankine’s prize-winning book of poems, Citizen: An American Lyric, incorporates the poetics of documentary in multiple ways, from the print text to the series of videos that expand its content and audience. This course will examine the evolution of the documentary poem-- beginning with Muriel Rukeyser’s Book of the Dead—as we chart its specific intent to intervene upon history and to challenge the archival record. We will take up issues concerning the construction of a historical archive—how it functions, what it includes and what it excludes; the role of the cell phone camera and video as it contests and challenges more traditional versions of “the facts”; the relationship between poetry and history--with a particular interest in the power of poetry in the political arena of human rights and environmental survivance.
This course requires a commitment to close reading and an engaged discussion of the assigned texts. Assignments will include a series of short critical essays, take home quizzes, an investigative notebook, and a final creative project.

name: Topics in Popular Culture                                            Dead is the New Alive: The Zombie Metaphor in Contemporary Fiction, Film, and TV
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Just as the metaphor of the vampire rose from the historical and cultural conditions at the end of the nineteenth century and found resonance with many of the concerns of modernism throughout the twentieth, the metaphor of the zombie has become pervasive in the condition of postmodernity. In late twentieth and early twenty-first century fiction, films, and television, zombies are everywhere. Why? And what cultural functions does this pervasive metaphor serve? Indeed, is the zombie metaphor the perfect emblem for the salient concerns of postmodernism, combining as it does a critique of mass consumerism with fears of contagion and the breakdown of technocultural control, while providing an all-purpose scapegoat for a wide range of bigotries?
This course will be grounded in the reading of a range of print zombie narratives, including comics, novels, and ephemera. It will survey, sample, and occasionally screen zombie films and zombies on TV. It will consider the phenomenon of zombie video games and zombie-themed creations on the web.   
Popular culture has always found ways to tap and reflect our secret fears and desires and then to increasingly colonize the public imaginary. So, what’s with all of these zombies?
Work for the class will require short reading quizzes, a take-home midterm and a take-home final, a zombie book review, and a zombie-related class presentation. That may sound like a lot, but it really isn’t.
 Books (available at Prairie Lights):
World War Z. Max Brooks
Zone One. Colson Whitehead
A Questionable Shape. Bennett Sims
Warm Bodies. Isaac Marion
The Girl With All The Gifts.  M. R. Carey
The Reapers Are The Angels. Alden Bell.
Zombie Haiku: Good Poetry For Your Brains. Ryan Mecum
Aim for the Head. An Anthology of Zombie Poetry. Rob “Ratpack“ Sturma. Ed.

name: Science Fiction                                            New Wave Science Fiction and the Counter Culture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The political and social upheavals of the 1960s saw a surprising correspondence in the evolution of science fiction. America’s changing social consciousness was reflected in changes also in priority for the genre, such that looking forward meant not only new tech and science but emerging issues in racial justice, shifting possibilities for gender and sexual identities, even alternative experiences of reality. Sometimes these needs were met by so-called “soft” science fiction, based around social rather than empirical sciences, and sometimes this meant classic storylines given a new twist--alien encounters defined less by technological differences and more by psychological ones, the colonization of planets complicated less by resource concerns and more by ethical ones. In this class we will explore the post-60s standouts in science fiction, their impetuses and aesthetics, which helped distinguish the genre as forward thinking scientifically, socially, and artistically.
Readings for this course include:Do Androids Dream 978-0345404473Slaughterhouse-V 978-0385333849Babel-17 978-0375706691The Female Man 978-0807062999The Lathe of Heaven 978-1416556961Lilith’s Brood 978-0446676106

name: Language and Learning
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Reading & Teaching Adolescent Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: 16th- and 17th-Century Poetry                                            Politics of English Poetry: Spenser, Jonson, Marvell, Dryden
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Early modern Britain underwent rapid transformation from a small nation on the margin of Europe to a major colonial and cultural power. The appearance of revolutionary movements and secular political parties helped usher in the modern age. Edmund Spenser, Ben Jonson, Andrew Marvell, and John Dryden did not view these events from a distant gallery but actively involved themselves in politics, which penetrated into almost every corner of their world, including religion, literature, trade, and the role of women. By cutting across traditional literary periods the course opens new perspectives on four poetic careers as they took place over time and in history.   The goal of the course is to study four poetic careers as they unfold in specific political contexts: Spenser's celebration of Queen Elizabeth and her Irish policies; Jonson's status as a remnant of Elizabethan culture and publicist for the Stuart myth; Marvell's experimentation with various poetic styles, culminating in a densely allusive topical satire; and Dryden's attempts to shape public opinion and follow the migrations of power throughout his life. 
Requirements include two papers (50%); two quizzes (10% each); an in-class presentation (10%); attendance and participation (20%)
Required Texts 

R.O. Bucholz, and Newton Key, Early Modern England, 1485-1714: A Narrative History. 2nd ed. (Wiley-Blackwell, 2009) ISBN: 978-1405162753 
Spenser, The Faerie Queene, Book Five, ed. A. Stoll (Hackett, 2006). ISBN: 978-0872208018 
Jonson, Selected Masques, ed. S. Orgel (Yale UP, 1970). ISBN: 9780300012590 
Marvell, The Complete Poems, ed. E. S. Donno (Penguin, 2005). ISBN: 978-0140424577 
Dryden, Selected Poems, ed. S. Zwicker and D. Bywaters (Penguin, 2002). ISBN: 978-0140439144 

Books are available for purchase at the University Bookstore, IMU.
We will screen the following films in class, which are also placed on reserve in Main Library.

Queen Christina, dir. Rouben Mamoulian (1933).   
To Kill a King, dir. Mike Barker (2003).  
Winstanley, dir. Kevin Brownlow and Andrew Mollo (1975).

name: The English Bible
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course might also be subtitled “The Bible for English Majors.” It approaches the Bible – the single most influential book on the Anglophone literary tradition – from the perspective of literary studies and a readership-based approach.  We will read widely in the Old and New Testaments as well as in the “Apocrypha” or deuterocanonical books, gaining familiarity with the biblical stories, figures, and phrases that color English and American literature, reading them with a literary sensitivity to plot and story, narrative and poetic structure, and metaphor. In other words, we will be reading the Bible as literature students, creative writers, and English majors. We will also read a range of texts by readers of the Bible from the Protestant, Roman Catholic, and patristic/Eastern Christian traditions, seeking to situate ourselves and our ways of reading the Bible among the variety of communities and interpretive sensibilities that have created the amazing imaginative richness surrounding this text over the last 2,000 years.  Approaching the Bible in this way will give students the ability to understand literary references to the Bible in a variety of meaningful ways and to ponder the significance of these stories, hymns, and poems in a secular or postsecular age. Students in this class will participate in lively class discussion, take notes on the readings and class sessions, write two short papers, visit Special Collections as part of an in-class project, and take two exams.   Reading List: The New Oxford Annotated Bible With Apocrypha (Oxford UP, ISBN-13: 9780195289558) St. Gregory of Nyssa, The Life of Moses (HarperCollins Spiritual Classics: ISBN-13: 978-0060754648) Early Christian Writings: The Apostolic Fathers, ed. Andrew Louth (Penguin Classics: ISBN-13: 978-0140444759) Mary Gordon, Reading Jesus: A Writer’s Encounter with the Gospels (Anchor, 2010: ISBN-13: 978-0307277626)

name: Chaucer                                            The Canterbury Tales
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course will center on the Canterbury Tales, in the original (initially tough but ultimately enjoyable) Middle English. Our goal will be to achieve a nuanced understanding of this brilliant work in terms of Chaucer's literary and historical contexts. We will as well gain a sense of the contemporary critical debates that have shaped thinking on the poem over the long twentieth century. We will devote special attention to the category of “the human” as it emerges in Chaucer’s poetry and has been rethought over recent years by post-humanists. We will consider our own understandings of what it means to be a human, what it means to live the best human life and the role of literature in fostering such a life. We will consider how Chaucer, and medieval culture more broadly, portray humanity in relation to the non-human or less-than-human (e.g., monsters, Jews, Muslims, sodomites, women, children, animals, objects). I require close reading skills for all written assignments and for class discussion.

name: Shakespeare                                            Shakespeare's Villains
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In 1601, a young law student in London copied down an anecdote in which a besotted playgoer arranged a rendezvous with the lead actor of Shakespeare’s company, the famous Richard Burbage, while he was still in costume as the most infamous villain in English history, King Richard III. As the story goes, Shakespeare heard of the rendezvous and usurped Burbage’s place with the punchline that “William the Conqueror was before Richard III.” This apocryphal story shows how strangely seductive the character of Richard III was, despite—or perhaps because of—his unrelenting evil, manifested in his disfigured body. As the recent global media frenzy over the rediscovery of the historical Richard’s skeleton (buried beneath a parking lot) shows, Richard remains an undeniably attractive figure for us. Indeed, audiences and readers continue to be drawn to the greatest villains in Shakespeare’s works.
This course will attempt to explain our ongoing fascination with Shakespeare’s villains by defining, re-defining, and upending our notions of what constitutes villainy. Characters like Richard III and Iago have long embodied and epitomized the Shakespearean villain—but the role of the villain, and even the term “villain,” were far more complicated. As such, we will focus not only on plays that feature famous villains, but on unexpected plays that will force us to reconsider what villainy meant for Shakespeare—and what it continues to mean for us.
We will spend much of our time reading the plays closely and critically, in order to become both familiar and comfortable with reading Shakespeare’s dynamic language. We will also learn about the professional theatre in which Shakespeare worked, and in which his plays were first staged, as well as the ways these plays have been performed, altered, and adapted over the subsequent centuries. We will encounter and use supplementary readings, online resources, and film versions that contextualize and galvanize the plays.
Course requirements will include active engagement in class discussion; a series of short exercises and writing assignments; and an individual critical or creative project. Readings will include Richard III, Romeo and Juliet, Othello, and Macbeth.

name: Literature & Culture of 19th Cen Britain
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
The nineteenth century was an era of major changes in British life--in industry, science, education, transportation, technology, women’s roles, and political inclusion. Victorians of all classes responded acutely and often critically to their society, as manifested in the essays, fiction, poetry, drama, and art of the period. We will examine writings of the period 1830-1900 with attention to the social milieu which fostered them, the circumstances of publication and audience response, prominent linguistic and thematic features, relationship to other writings of the period, and possible contemporary relevance.
This course is discussion based; students are expected to prepare for class discussion, submit short on-line postings and two 6 page essays, and give a class presentation.
Course texts will include:
Mary Barton; Elizabeth Gaskell; ISBN 1551111691
Bleak House; Charles Dickens; ISBN B01185X0CA
News from Nowhere;William Morris; ISBN-10 1551112671 The Time Machine; H.G. Wells; ISBN-10 0393927946 The History of Mary Prince; Sarah Silah; ISBN-10 0140437495

name: British Fiction                                            Victorian Fiction
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement.AREA: Modern British Literature and Culture. PERIOD: 18th/19th-Century Literature for Fall 2017.
Throughout the semester we will read compelling and influential works of nineteenth-century fiction, and consider ways in which these embodied features of Victorian life and sensibility. In particular, we will discuss how Victorian fiction  reflected patterns of marriage and family structure, class differences, forms of work and religious practice, views of art, urbanization, colonial empire, and efforts at social reform.
In the process, we will also consider questions of style, form, narrative sequence, authorial voice, modes of publication and intended audience(s), and changing tastes in critical reception.
I will ask students to read our texts with care and submit reading responses before each class session, participate actively in class discussions, provide background biographical information, contribute to a group project exploring some aspect of one of our texts, and submit two six-eight page essays. Some of our novels are quite long; students are advised not to enroll unless they are able to devote considerable time to these readings.
Course texts will include:
Mary Barton; Elizabeth Gaskell; ISBN 1551111691
Bleak House; Charles Dickens; ISBN B01185X0CA
News from Nowhere; William Morris; ISBN10 1551112671
Silas Marner; George Eliot; ISBN B00HTK6J9A
The Time Machine; H.G. Wells; ISBN-10 0393927946
To the Lighthouse; Virginia Woolf; ISBN B00HTjOQV4
Villette; Charlotte Bronte; 185326072X.

name: Topics in American Literature After 1900                                            In Print/In Person
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Even before being designated the world’s third UNESCO City of Literature, Iowa City was a magnet for practicing writers.  Some teach in the Writers’ Workshop or the Nonfiction Writing Program, some visit and read from their work, some just move in and stay.  This is the class for finding out why many of the writers hereabouts are winning national and international recognition.  Every week or so, we will prepare for the visit of an acclaimed writer by reading and discussing work that has just been published.  Lecturing will be brief; with writing so recently in print, this will be a class full of discovery, particularly when writers visit in person.
Books will be available at Prairie Lights.  We will likely be reading 9 authors, divided evenly (if sometimes ambiguously) among fiction, nonfiction, and poetry.  Coursework will include a reading journal with weekly postings and then a choice: two 5-6 pp papers on differing genres or a single paper coupled with class participation. No exams, but plenty of reason to draw conclusions about the writing that’s helping to define contemporary creative possibility.

name: Topics in American Literature After 1900                                            William Faulkner and the Question of Regionalism
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: In this class, we will read and analyze five of William Faulkner’s major novels: The Sound and the Fury, As I Lay Dying, Light in August, Absalom, Absalom!, and Go Down, Moses. This extraordinary corpus constitutes one of the major accomplishments of American modernism, and we will treat it as such, comparing the Bard of Oxford’s aesthetic strategies to those of Eliot, Joyce, Woolf, Hemingway, Pound, Stein, and other literary giants. At the same time, we will tease from Faulkner’s works ample reason to employ an alternate methodology that examines popular culture, focuses on neglected geographies, and attends carefully to questions of race, class, gender, and sexuality.  Our critical orientation will be two-fold.  We will balance social and historical analysis of each novel with careful examination of its aesthetic qualities.

name: Native American Literature
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course offers students a survey of the oral traditions and printed literature produced by American Indian people from the nineteenth through the twenty-first centuries. Our readings will include works by Joy Harjo (Muskogee), Delphine Red Shirt (Lakota), Thomas King, and many others. This English Department course is an Associated Course in the American Indian/Native Studies Program at the University of Iowa. As such, it seeks "to foster greater awareness of the richness of Native cultures, among Native and non-Native students" through the study of American Indian literature. Course requirements include a mid-term, final, and paper.
 
Required reading:
Bead on an Ant HillRed ShirtISBN: 0803289766Bison BooksBlack Eagle ChildYoung BearISBN: 0802134289Grove PressIn Mad Love and War HarjoISBN: 081951182XWesleyanLove MedicineErdrichISBN: 0061787426HarperOcean PowerZepedaISBN: 0816515417U of Arizona Riding the Earthboy 40WelchISBN: 0143034391Penguin StorytellerSilkoISBN: 0143121286Penguin The Seven Visions of Bull LodgeHorse Capture, ed.ISBN: 0803272561Nebraska Winter in the BloodWelchISBN: 0143105221Penguin

name: African American Literature Before 1900
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course examines some of the pivotal works of late eighteenth-, nineteenth-, and early twentieth-century African American literature. Throughout the semester, we will analyze the fictional representation of early African American life in the United States. We will also discuss: early versions of the African American novel; the black American’s transition from slavery to nominal freedom; male and female slave narratives; comparisons of the literary portrayals of black life in the North and the South; the controversies associated with racial passing; the role of “Negro” dialect in American and African American literature; literary and visual representations of lynching; and early cinematic representations of the black image. 
Among the questions we will consider are: How did writers critique America’s discriminatory practices as well as intra-racial class and color prejudices? What were the influences of popular culture on the literature of the period? How did the Civil War and the continual threat of lynching affect black creative methods and philosophy? We will also look at the African American literary image created by other American writers such as Stephen Crane, Herman Melville, and Mark Twain, and the legal decisions and political compromises that affected the construction of African American personhood (such as the Dred Scott v. Sanford and the Plessy v. Ferguson Supreme Court decisions). There will be a significant focus on the writings of Charles Chesnutt, one of the most prolific early African American writers and an author who wrote in the 19th and early 20th centuries. 
Readings will be supplemented by films and audio recordings. Class requirements include quizzes, class participation, one paper, a mid-term, and a final exam.  
Reading list:
Paul Laurence Dunbar, The Sport of the Gods• ISBN-10: 1614278261• ISBN-13: 978-1614278269Octavia Butler, Kindred• ISBN-10: 0807083690• ISBN-13: 978-0807083697John Hope Franklin, Three Negro Classics• ISBN-10: 0380015811• ISBN-13: 978-0380015818Herman Melville, Benito Cereno and Bartleby, ISBN:1619493799Charles Chesnutt, The Marrow of Tradition • ISBN-10: 1420937987• ISBN-13: 978-1420937985Frederick Douglass and Harriet Jacobs, Slave Narratives (Modern Library Edition), ASIN: B0043AWXVM

name: Identity and Social Issues                                            Down on the Farm: Exploring the Transnational Borders of Agriculture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
English majors may apply this course to the following area and/or period requirement. AREA: Transnational Literature and Postcolonial Studies. PERIOD: 18th/19th century literature for Fall 2017.
If you grew up in the United States, you have probably heard, “American farmers feed the world.” What if we expand our notion of America to include Canada, Latin America, and the Caribbean? After all, much of the produce lining supermarket shelves was grown in Chile and Mexico. The Americas have a rich agricultural legacy—for instance, giving the world potatoes, squash, tomatoes, and, of course, corn. Therefore, this course will approach the study of literature of the farm within a Hemispheric context, emphasizing how the movement of people (migration and immigration), information, and goods influences literary representations of farming and farm life. After reading works by Hawthorne, Whitman, Susanna Moodie, Jorge Isaacs, and Gertrudis Gomez de Avellaneda, among others, you should have a deeper understanding of how technology, labor, information, and the economy shape agriculture and how farming in turn drives change. This class will be useful for students interested in nineteenth-century American literature, nineteenth-century literature of the Americas, and the environmental humanities. 
Students will be responsible for readings, keeping a reading journal, writing two short essays, and a final paper.
Booklist:

Hector St. John de Crevecoeur, Letters from an American Farmer, Penguin, ISBN-13:978-0140390063


Black Hawk, Life of Black Hawk, Penguin, ISBN-13:978-0143105398


Gertrudis Gomez de Avellaneda y Artega, Sab and Autobiography, University of Texas Press, ISBN-13:978-0292704428


Maria Ruiz de Barton, The Squatter and the Don, Modern Library, ISBN-13:978-0812972894


Helena Maria Viramontes, Under the Feet of Jesus, Plume, ISBN-13:978-0452273870

name: International Literature Today
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
During the first eight weeks of the semester, this course draws on the presence and work of the writers in residence at the International Writing Program. The literature represented includes current writings from Africa, Asia and the Pacific, Latin America, Europe, and the Middle East. Text materials (short fiction, poetry, excerpts from plays) are available on the course web site. The authors speak about their own writing and how their work relates to the literary scene in their countries. Literary issues such as translation, censorship, women's writing, and some background historical, political, or cultural information may be discussed in defining the specific literary context of a work, but the course focuses on the writing itself, its artistry and themes. During the remaining weeks of the semester, students read and discuss several contemporary literary works, both poetry and prose, with special attention to the themes brought alive by the visiting writers.
First year students and sophomores with interest in world literature are welcome in the class, and should be able to complete the assignments successfully.
Students' participation includes preparing weekly questions for the visitors, keeping a journal, as well as two papers (for 3 s.h.).

name: Writing About Girls
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In this course we will look at a wide range of critical and creative works by contemporary women writers on girlhood and adolescence. Students will examine the gender scripts girls learn and often resist; the nature of girls’ friendships; issues of body, sexuality, and identify, the role of race and class in girls’ lives; and new narratives and forms for girls’ stories including fan fiction, video games, and comics.  Requirements for this course include occasional short critical and creative reading responses; three unit take home tests; participation in class discussion, including twice assuming the role of class discussion leader; and a final writer’s project on an aspect of Girl Culture most interesting and relevant to each student.  Course materials will include excerpts from Girls’ Studies books and articles, videos and films, contemporary news stories, and these texts, available at Prairie Lights Bookstore in Iowa City:
 
Margaret Atwood, Cat’s Eye
Susan Kuklin, Beyond Magenta; Transgender Teens Speak Out
Toni Morrison, The Bluest Eye
Michelle Tea, Without a Net: The Female Experience of Growing Up Working Class
Noelle Stevenson, Grace Ellis, and Shannon Watters. Lumberjanes, Vol 1 Beware the Kitten Holy
Willow Wilson, Ms. Marvel Volume 1: No Normal

name: Undergraduate Translation Workshop
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: "The most fundamental description of what translators do is that we write." —Edith Grossmann This introductory workshop seeks to explore that relationship between translating and writing.  Students will be exposed to a broad range of ideas about translation through weekly readings combined with weekly writing exercises and workshop-style discussions of student work. Students will work toward a final translation project suited to their particular language interests and abilities. This course in open to anyone interested in translation. Working knowledge of another language is useful, though not required. All readings will be made available on ICON.

name: Honors Seminar: American Lit, 20/21 C                                            Writing and War
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This seminar will begin by posing the following simple question:  Are there any lessons that we, as students of literature, can or should derive from the perhaps surprising fact that, when asked to name books that had had the greatest influence in their lives, both Senator John McCain and President Barack Obama invoked Ernest Hemingway’s classic novel of the Spanish Civil War, For Whom the Bell Tolls? We will, of course, read the novel ourselves, and then we will use our resulting conversations (e.g., Are Democrats and Republicans not that different after all? Does great writing transcend ideology?) as a springboard for surveying subsequent classic (e.g., Catch-22, The Things They Carried, In Country) and contemporary (e.g., Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk, Sand Queen, Sparta, War Porn) American writing about war. Our primary focus will be fiction, but we certainly won’t rule out making brief excursions into nonfiction and poetry to broaden our understanding of the forms that this writing takes. We will, of necessity, also devote time to the problem of gatekeeping—for example, what counts as a “war novel” in the first place and who gets to decide?
