name: Speaking and Reading
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: THIS COURSE IS NOT AVAILABLE TO REGULAR, ON-CAMPUS STUDENTS. YOU CANNOT ENROLL in this course unless you are a degree candidate for the UI Bachelor of Liberal Studies, Bachelor of Applied Studies, RN-BSN, Des Moines BA Social Work, or online Bachelor of Business Administration degree.   The speaking portion of the accelerated course is an introductory course in speaking required of students who have completed a college-level writing course but have not previously had an equivalent college or university speech course. Intended to improve speaking, listening, and critical and analytical skills, the course involves preparing and presenting four speech assignments and several critical reading assignments. This section of Speaking and Reading fulfills the General Education Program requirement in Rhetoric for University of Iowa Bachelor of Liberal Studies students, Bachelor of Applied Studies students, RN-BSN students, Des Moines BA Social Work students, and online Bachelor of Business Administraion students only. If you are a degree candidate in any other undergraduate program at The University of Iowa, you are not allowed to enroll in this independent study course. If you are not admitted to a degree program at The University of Iowa, you may enroll. However, if you are subsequently admitted to an undergraduate degree program at The University of Iowa, this independent study course will not satisfy the General Education Program requirement in Rhetoric. ASSIGNMENT SUBMISSION: Students will record presentations for several assignments and submit them via e-mail or by mail on a DVD or CD-Rom (VHS is also accepted.) This is a Guided Independent Study (self-paced) Course. You have the option of utilizing two academic terms to complete GIS courses. Completion of this course requires Internet access. Note: If you are an international student you must complete the course during the initial semester. If you have questions please consult International Student and Scholar Services (http://international.uiowa.edu/isss/)This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Big Ideas: Creativity for a Lifetime
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
In Creativity for a Lifetime, students will learn the significance of creativity in human happiness and success. Creativity is part of what makes us human, and understanding the creative process is relevant to all of us. In this course, we will examine questions about big ideas, such as: What is creativity and how can we be more creative? What can we learn from closely examining our own and others’ creative work? What is the role of creativity across the human lifespan? How can creative work be a part of healthy adult life and healthy aging? We will especially consider the lives and work of artists. Because artists intensively imagine things that don’t yet exist, understanding artist’s experiences will enhance innovation and imagination. Students in the arts, liberal arts, sciences, and social sciences can apply the experience gained from studying the outcomes of creativity and working with established artists to other academic disciplines.
Students will engage in activities and projects as opposed to lectures and exams. Taught in an active-learning TILE classroom, Creativity for a Lifetime brings together the knowledge, skills, and life experiences of students and faculty members interested in an array of disciplines, including art and art history, anthropology, education, rhetoric, social work, aging studies, and the health sciences. To better appreciate the elements of successful aging, the richness of life-long learning, and an appreciation of the role of creative endeavor throughout a lifespan, students will meet Iowa artists and collect their oral histories.
This section of the course is reserved for students who also enroll for the associated section of Honors Rhetoric using One-Click Course Combinations, Courses in Common. Students who enroll in this Courses in Common option will earn Honors credit for the associated Rhetoric course. Students enrolled in both courses will earn Honors credit for this Big Ideas course if they earn a B- or better.

name: Persuasion and Advocacy                                            Cowgirl Stories
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Stories about cowgirls feature women who are at home in their bodies, connected with nature, and, often times, disrupting traditional gender roles. What is it about girls and horses that captures and holds the imagination well into adulthood? This course will look at cowgirl stories in our culture from a variety of viewpoints and in a number of cultural forms: songs, television shows, films, essays, and books. Guided by the rich and multiple ways our culture links cowgirl stories to themes of freedom and rebellion, students will do a number of short, multimodal assignments designed to explore how cowgirl stories influence our desire to subvert or seek traditional gender roles. In performing these short assignments, students will analyze and transform the many cowgirl stories existing in our culture to stake their own credible claim. The final project will draw directly from these short assignments and offer students the opportunity to showcase their work in an online format to gain skills relevant for publishing on the web.

name: Persuading Different Audiences
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This new course will develop skills of persuasion in professional contexts, including skills of rhetorical flexibility, recognizing and pursuing opportunities, identifying and fostering collaborative relationships, planning and executing projects, and networking. Students will learn how to present themselves authentically and authoritatively in professional situations (in interviews, in internships, in graduate school, on the job).  Students design professional aspirations and use course projects to present a professional identity in communal, business, and social media settings.
 
Course Readings:
Speaking as a Leader by Judith Humphrey
One biography or autobiography of student’s choice
Readings in grammar and rhetoric as assigned
 
Grading:
 
Participation: 15%
Collaborative public engagement project: 15%
Case study project--students “apprentice” themselves to a notable persuader: 20%
Personal branding project: 20%
Professional portfolio—students create a website: 30%

name: Speaking Skills
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course helps students become confident and effective speakers; assignments include formal presentations and shorter, informal speaking activities; peer and instructor feedback helps students to improve the impression they create as speakers; strengths developed include earning credibility, capturing and maintaining audience interest, and coming across as personable, professional, and confident.

name: Conversation Practicum
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course counts towards the Rhetoric Minor, and earns students who are member of University Honors 3 s.h. of honors experiential learning credit.

name: Acting for Success
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Advanced Speaking Skills
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Writing to Change the World
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course is designed for students who would like to make a difference in the world, especially (but not necessarily) the every day world outside the academy. We will collaborate to select three or four public controversies relevant to the students who sign up for the course, and examine the kinds of advocacy around them.
As we examine the circumstances and controversies that condition the lived experience of the students, each student will undertake a project designed to intervene in a public controversy. The form of advocacy will be negotiated: the class is open to advocacy in a multitude or genres and media. The criteria for evaluation will be engagement, passion, efficacy, knowledge and wisdom.

name: Narratives of Gender and Masculinity
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Over the last twenty-five years, theorists in a variety of disciplines have been developing an appreciation of narrative in the cultural and social construction of reality, including human identity. Our identities are conditioned by the stories we tell about ourselves, and the stories our societies encourage us to tell.
In this class, we will read theoretical material that introduces current thinking about the work that narrative does in the creation of identities, as well as material theorizing gender, especially masculinity. We will apply the insights we gain to narratives we find in the culture around us, from the classroom to the world at large. The critical analysis we do will be—broadly—ethnographic in its orientation, and I hope that students will be inclined to take an auto ethnographic turn in their production of a semester long project of research, analysis and—potentially—advocacy.

name: Advocacy and Sustainability
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
"Sustainable” is a popular modifier, used to alter how we view the other words in close proximity: food, agriculture, energy, resource management, design, business, economies, models, programs, development, cities, and the more encompassing terms of place and space.  While each application develops and adopts sets of practices, how do these assemble to reveal a clearer picture of value, purpose, and intent? What are the sources for the critical terms defining “sustainability?” What narratives are used to influence, inform, and persuade? How might visual and audio combine with design, cartography, hard data, cultural mythology, marketing, research, and personal narrative?
This course takes a more interrogative, exploratory approach to the use and possibilities of “sustainability”. Evidence, analysis, creative and critical thinking will combine to shape our discussion of various texts, arguments, positions, and examinations of what is, what isn’t, and what could become ‘sustainable.’We’ll observe and investigate its more tangible, application in communities: small, local, large and global. We will take a closer read of “sustainability” as it is practiced, understood, argued, applied and misused/abused. We will look at systemic infrastructure and how “sustainability” offers challenge, demands risk, and engages possibility. Our scholarship will be active, interactive, personal, collaborative, “owned” and part of an emerging “creative and resilient commons.” Students will work individually and collaborate to develop, research, produce, and refine multimedia projects of their own chosen topic.
This course is open to both undergraduate and graduate students. Previous offerings have revealed this to be a very productive and beneficial approach.

name: Special Projects for Undergraduates
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Special Projects for Undergraduates                                            Supplemental Instruction in Rhetoric
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
A talented teacher makes teaching appear effortless, but the art of teaching is anything but. If you’re considering teaching as a career or enjoy tutoring, the Supplemental Instruction in Rhetoric (SIR) Practicum provides the opportunity to practice the art of peer-to-peer teaching. Leaders will create lessons that teach critical speaking, reading, writing, and listening skills to students enrolled in Rhetoric. Leaders will be supported by course instructors throughout the practicum. Instructors and leaders will meet for one hour each week of the semester.
The first three weeks of the SIR Practicum will be spent discussing, reading, and honing best teaching practices such as, but not limited to: lesson planning, facilitating group sessions, motivating students, and Rhetoric pedagogy. After the third week of the semester (in addition to attending the SIR Practicum course one hour each week) SIR leaders will facilitate two SIR review sessions per week providing instruction to Rhetoric students until week fifteen of the semester. Practicum instructors will observe leaders’ teaching and provide constructive feedback at least two times during the semester. At the end of the semester, leaders will have compiled eleven weeks of lesson plans, two course observations, and teaching experience for their resume and/or teaching portfolio. The semester will conclude with teaching portfolio presentations reflecting on your experiences. There is no midterm or final exam.
The scheduling of practicum and peer-led tutoring sessions will be determined based on leaders’ schedules. Though specific times are to be determined, leaders should expect to hold sessions throughout the week and some evenings. Course registration is by permission only. Interested students must have completed Rhetoric to be eligible for the practicum. In addition, applicants must submit a letter of interest and one recommendation from a Rhetoric instructor or writing-based instructor. Application materials may be e-mailed to dana-thomann@uiowa.edu.  As this course is meant to facilitate peer-to-peer tutoring, only undergraduate students will be considered.

name: Practicum: College Teaching for TAs
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Guidance for TAs seeking introduction to college teaching; focus on practical pedagogical concerns, including course planning, developing materials, evaluating student work, creating a student-centered classroom. Includes a pre-semester intensive training session.

name: Directing a Writing Center
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Directing a Speaking Center
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Colloquium: Teaching Rhetoric
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Professional Development Program (PDP) for all new Rhetoric teachers. Graduate students must enroll for credit (graded S/U). Includes three-day pre-semester Workshop.

name: Teaching in a Writing Center
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The primary purpose of this seminar/practicum is to prepare students to work in the Writing Center at the University of Iowa and/or other institutions. A secondary purpose is to introduce students to some important themes in writing studies. Students read articles, books, handouts, and web pages on the following related issues: reading and writing processes, one-on-one conferencing dynamics, second language writing, basic writing, first- and second-year college writing, writing across the curriculum, and writing center administration. Students keep a weekly journal in which they apply course readings to tutoring their own writing center students. An oral report on a case study of a student writer or on a resource for tutoring writing as well as a final written project are required. For more information, please e-mail Carol Severino at carol-severino@uiowa.edu.

name: Writing in the Disciplines
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course prepares graduate students for the tasks of writing in their home disciplines and moving between different rhetorical registers in their professional writing. The course addresses a variety of genres germane to graduate writing (cover letters, dissertation chapters, grant proposals, etc.) while making room for more discipline-specific forms such as posters and websites. We will discuss the practice of communicating the same information in different forms and styles as well as the particular limits and advantages of doing so.
The course fosters cross-disciplinary conversations about writing conventions and practices while refining discipline-specific writing strategies and pedagogy. Students will pursue pragmatic, tangible outcomes over the course of the semester. Students should be prepared to bring ongoing writing projects to class, as time will be devoted to workshopping student writing.
This course has immediate value for graduate students who will be competing for jobs that require them to communicate across disciplinary boundaries and in a variety of modes. Course instruction will be supplemented by guest speakers from departments across the University as we work together to foster interdisciplinary communication and collaboration.

name: First-Year Seminar                                            How Dogs Shape Our Lives
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
How Dogs Shape Our Lives explores the changing nature our relationship with dogs. The course is organized around one guiding question: What is the role of dogs in human cultures? Through weekly readings, class discussion, short written assignments and a group project this course will have you explore the evolution of human-dog interactions, and hopefully challenge and expand your view of the various roles dogs play in our lives, such as pet/companion, worker/service animal, food source, and entertainer. The course will begin with students exploring how dogs first evolved alongside Paleolithic and Neolithic human groups. We will then critically examine the moral, ethical, and cultural issues related to how we treat and interact with dogs in the modern world. Finally, we will consider how personal and cultural customs and practices are expressed through our interaction with dogs. 
This course introduces students to how the study of social sciences and humanities have been used to engage big questions about who we are, how we live our life, and how we chose to interact with other species on this planet. Throughout the semester students will confront important questions, such as: How have human lives and society changed over time and across space? How do changes in the structure and organization of human social and political systems affect our treatment of non-human animals. What are the key moral and ethical issues related to people having power over animals?

name: First-Year Seminar                                            A Tour of Biological Anthropology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: A Tour of Biological Anthropology: Explore the diverse field of biological anthropology and learn about many of the ways that knowledge of human biology can inform us about how people have evolved, migrated, and adapted to the many regions of the world we now inhabit. Learn about the research that paleoanthropologists, human geneticists, bioarchaeologists, and forensic anthropologists are doing, as well as opportunities for undergraduate study in these fields. Participate in visits to the University of Iowa Museum of Natural History and the collections and working labs of the Office of the State Archaeologist. Participate in hands-on lab exercises that will introduce you to the analysis of human skeletal remains. Class participation counts for a large part of final grades, so attendance is a must. Weekly readings and classes will introduce a great diversity of topics, and opportunities to further explore particular fields of study within biological anthropology will be provided by a few short essay assignments. This course only requires about 2 hours of outside work per week and is an excellent, interactive way to learn about what anthropology has to offer.

name: Issues in Anthropology                                            Anthropological Forensics
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Anthropological Forensics: We are all familiar with popular television depictions of crime scene investigation. The work of a real-world forensic anthropologist, though far less glamorous than portrayed in the media, is just as intellectually stimulating. This course examines the topics of forensic anthropology and crime scene investigation through a realistic, applied approach. The course will begin with a brief history of forensic anthropology, followed by an overview of human osteology. Other covered topics will include how to approach a crime scene and how to distinguish between remains found in historical versus modern contexts. We will also examine postmortem processes affecting the human body, including decay rates in different environmental contexts and forensic entomology. This will lead us to techniques of estimating time since death and of determining the age, sex, and ancestry of a skeleton. We will also look at problem-solving case studies in forensic anthropology. This course will deal with mature subjects in a respectful manner, and will present graphic images of the postmortem human body. Discretion is advised.

name: Language Rights
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Imagine any of the following:
You start school as a child are not taught in your home language, the only one you speak well.
You are arrested by the police, but you don’t understand the language they speak.
You go to the Department of Motor Vehicles or another government office, and the people speak to you in an unfamiliar language.
You talk to your friends in public but can’t use the language you use with them in private.
Your parents give you one name, but the government insists you be called something else.
How would your life be affected by this?
All around the world these very things happen.
In this course we examine issues of linguistic human rights: the fundamental right to use one's language and the efforts made to secure those rights and deny them. We explore how language rights are integral to human rights in general and an individual's definition of personal and cultural identity through studying a variety of case studies of the abrogation of language rights locally, nationally, and internationally. Course requirements include one midterm exam, three 1-2 page observation papers, a 7-10 page final paper on a case of language rights.

name: Big Ideas: People and the Environment                                            Technology, Culture, and Social Justice
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
ANTH:1046:0001 (113:046:0002) People and the Environment: Technology, Culture, and Social Justice (002 is paired with RHET:1030:05) this section is open to only incoming freshmen honor studentsThis section is paired with RHET:1030:0051. Students must enroll for both courses by using the Courses in Common option number 47. To enroll, students must be Honors students who have not yet fulfilled the General Education Rhetoric requirement. Pairing courses in this way will allow students to have a more sustained conversation around the course topics.
This is a course about ‘big questions’ related to environment and culture: How is my life connected to that of a village woman in India who spends hours cutting fuel wood to cook the family dinner? How is my life linked to global environmental change?  How should we live with the earth?  A team of five faculty will guide you through the process of addressing urgent, real world problems by focusing on the causes of environmental degradation in Rajasthan, India, in comparison with Iowa, in order to find possible solutions. We will explore how people, ideas and things cross borders - ‘globalization’- through issues of technology, social justice and environment by bringing together anthropology, gender studies, geography, energy science and development.  This course will promote critical thinking by prioritizing active learning via classroom activities, discussion and team work (facilitated by round tables in a TILE classroom), supplemented with short lectures.  Our emphasis will be on applying key concepts and models from both natural and social science to our case studies of India and the United States, a task that is both challenging and exciting.  Assignments will include weekly quizzes, exams, short essays, and a final research project.
 This section of the course is reserved for students who also enroll for the associated section of Honors Rhetoric using One-Click Course Combinations, Courses in Common. Students who enroll in this Courses in Common option will earn Honors credit for the associated Rhetoric course. Students enrolled in both courses will earn Honors credit for this Big Ideas course if they earn a B- or better.

name: Cultural Anthropology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: 'Culture' refers to the shared ideas and customary ways of doing things that human beings acquire as members of a social group.  Culture is inherent in the ways we feed, clothe, and shelter ourselves, order the world around us, coordinate our activities, relate to one another, and express our thoughts and feelings.  In short, culture is what constitutes a "way of life" – some aspects are nearly universal, others more specific to particular times and places.  This course is an introduction to the field of cultural anthropology – the comparative study of culture based on direct observations and experiences drawn from a wide range of human societies, both past and present.  The course is intended to (1) introduce the fundamental concepts that constitute the discipline of cultural anthropology, (2) promote a greater appreciation for the richness and diversity of culture throughout the world, and (3) provide students with a better understanding of other ways of life, as well as deeper insight into their own.

name: World Archaeology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The focus of this course is on the evolution of human culture from the hunters and gatherers of the Pleistocene (Ice Ages) to the complex societies of historically known civilizations. Cultures of both the Old and New Worlds are covered. Also provided is an introduction to the techniques of excavation, dating, analysis, and preservation of archaeological remains. Discussion sections supplement topics covered in class and include several graded assignments.

name: Human Origins
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Human evolutionary history began 5-7 million years ago in Africa and continues today around the world. What were the lives of our earliest ancestors like? What were the processes that led to modern human diversity? How accurate are media depictions of human evolution? What is the place of humans in the natural world? How does the behavior of other primates inform us about ourselves? Who were the Neanderthals and what is our relationship to them? These are among the topics that we will survey from the perspectives of evolutionary theory, comparative anatomy, genetics, and the fossil record. The course incorporates information and current interpretations gleaned from the most recent fossil discoveries. 
The course format includes two lectures per week and one discussion section.  In discussion sections, students learn the methods of biological anthropology through a variety of activities including hands-on study of cast fossil material and artifacts. Requirements include two midterm exams, one final exam, and discussion section quizzes and assignments.
This course satisfies the GER non-laboratory requirement in natural sciences.
Note: this course has proctored online exams. Local students will take exams in the DCE Testing Center (no charge). Off-campus students will take exams using an online proctored exam service. Off-campus students must have access to a computer with a webcam and headset/microphone in a quiet/private location. Off-campus students are responsible for proctoring fees (up to $20 per exam).This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Human Genetics in the 21st Century
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Discover your inner Neanderthal. Learn how DNA sequences can be used to look into the past to analyze human patterns of migration. For anyone that takes this class, you will probably have your genome sequenced in the relatively near future. Why? Because your genes affect virtually every aspect of your life, and certainly will be relevant to future health care decisions. This course is designed to acquaint you with your genome, and provide you with the basic information necessary to understand the flood of genetic information that is currently inundating society. This course is designed for students who do not intend to make a career in the sciences but are curious about themselves and the explosion of genetic information that began in the end of the 20th century, and continues to accelerate in the 21st century. No prior science or math skills beyond those required for admission to the University are required, but it is assumed that students have a basic grasp of algebra, and have been exposed to biology or chemistry.

name: Language, Culture, and Communication
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is an introduction to contemporary linguistic anthropology, the study of language use in comparative social and cultural contexts. We will cover some basic concepts from the theoretical perspectives of the discipline and explore a range of topics that show how language and ideas about language contribute to the construction of our reality and social worlds. We will consider how the effects of language use emerge from interactions beyond individual control, and will explore relationships between language and group identity, including categories of ethnicity and gender. We will examine how language use derives its authority from specific institutions that promote particular forms and deny access both within individual states and globally. We will also evaluate differences in language’s social power across media (spoken, written, signed) of communication. Along the way students will come to appreciate a view of human language as a particularly structured system of signs. The student who completes this course will have new tools for understanding the social significance of different forms of language use both with which she or he comes in contact on a daily basis and that exist across the globe.

name: Individual Study
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Anthropology & Contemporary World Problm
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course examines how anthropological approaches can help us understand and address significant social problems facing populations across the world. A key objective is that students develop the ability to apply key anthropological concepts to analyses of both endemic social problems and current events.  Special attention will be paid to ways that race, gender, and social and economic inequality shape world problems, and social responses to them, at levels from local to global.
Note: this course has proctored online exams. Local students will take exams in the DCE Testing Center (no charge). Off-campus students will take exams using an online proctored exam service. Off-campus students must have access to a computer with a webcam and headset/microphone in a quiet/private location. Off-campus students are responsible for proctoring fees (up to $20 per exam).This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Introduction to Global Health Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This class offers a comprehensive introduction to the field of Global Health studies. Bringing together approaches from the social sciences and epidemiology, the class analyzes key epidemics, debates and interventions from around the world. Students taking this course will be graded based upon weekly writing assignments, a midterm, a final research paper, attendance and participation. In an introductory course, the litmus test for student achievement is their willingness to learn and the effort to expand their knowledge of a subject. These will be the key predictors of student success in this course.
This section will be taught by Dr. Alberto Ortiz Diaz.

name: Food, Drink, and Culture
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is all about the passion of food, eating and drinking in our lives. Via lectures, discussion and (hopefully) sporadic food tasting sessions, you will be challenged to study eating and drinking in all its variety and importance in different contemporary cultures of the world. We shall explore: How and why food and drink hold the power to bind people together or to set groups apart. How are national cuisines made? How do people connect food and drink to ritual and health care systems? These questions and many more will be linked with the study of food and drink production and consumption to examine societal processes such as the construction of identities and symbolic meanings attached to eating and drinking.

name: Culture/Healing for Health Professionals
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Health professionals are increasingly called upon to understand the complex social and cultural dimensions of sickness and healing, in order to provide the best quality care to culturally diverse populations. Knowledge of how social, cultural and biological factors interact, both to produce disease and to influence the course of healing, is increasingly emphasized in entrance examinations for health-related graduate and professional programs (such as the Medical College Admissions Test, which will include new sections on these topics starting in 2015). This introductory-level course introduces key cultural and social influences on sickness and healing, illustrating with examples from throughout the globe and across the different subfields of anthropology. Sometimes called “the most humanistic of the sciences and the most scientific of the humanities,” anthropology offers well-developed concepts and numerous case studies that help to improve cross-cultural understanding of the social and biological foundations of human health. This course also emphasizes the development of critical reading skills that students need in order to best understand works from the medical social sciences and humanities.

name: The Invention of Writing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences

name: Practicum in Archaeology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is intended for students with strong archaeological interests or archaeological field experience.  The class studies a wide range of materials recently recovered from archaeological sites.  Pottery, lithics (stone tools and related items), plant remains, and animal bones are studied in an intensive, hands-on manner.If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Origins of Human Infectious Disease
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Emerging and reemerging pathogens, such as HIV and West Nile, are now a major threat to human health, while older diseases, such as malaria and tuberculosis, continue to kill millions of people worldwide each year. This course will explore how and why human pathogens evolve and what this means for patterns of human disease. Although a variety of infectious agents will be considered, the emphasis will be on those that cause serious mortality and morbidity in humans today. For each of the major classes of pathogen – viruses, bacteria and pathogenic eukaryotes – we will learn how genetic variation is generated, how the spread of these pathogens can be reconstructed using phylogenetic and other evolutionary techniques, and how they are able to evade host immune responses and cause disease in humans. Special emphasis will be given to new, emerging diseases, such as HIV and swine-origin influenza virus, and the evolutionary forces that allow these pathogens to jump into and establish themselves in modern human populations.

name: Lab Methods in Biological Anthropology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Introduction to Museum Studies
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Museums collect and preserve artifacts and objects from our world while reflecting the values, creativity, and aspirations of human culture. This course provides an overview of the past and present of museums while presenting possibilities for the future. Using case studies from a wide range of museums (e.g., art, history, natural history, science, culturally specific) this course will presents the foundations of museum studies and examines best practices and approaches to collection and curatorial practice; governance and operations; audience and community engagement; and ethical issues. This course also explores the wide range of career pathways available in the field and gives students hands-on experience through a service-learning project. This course engages students in activities and dialogue that contribute to a larger conversation about the significant role museums play in our society.

name: Independent Study
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Medical Anthropology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course uses ethnographic examples from around the world to examine the diverse ways people understand and intervene in health and illness. We will study the relationships between culture and medical practice, understanding healing systems - ranging from biomedicine to sorcery - as cultural systems themselves. We will learn how these systems’ varied understandings of bodies and health make sense in different social and structural contexts. We will also study the ways that political, structural, and social settings influence bodily health. Topics covered include: stigma, lifestyle drugs, HIV/AIDS, chronic illness, disability and dying.

name: Religion and Healing
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Religious and spiritual healing have been deployed as a major part of medical practice for thousands of years and, conversely, healing has been a major part of religious practice for as long as religion has existed. Just as most forms of traditional medical practice have experimented with, and in many cases have established, procedures for enacting healing ritual, religious practice throughout the world has historically included specified prayer and other forms of individual and collective procedures designed to augment the healing process. This includes practices designed not only for what we in the West define as mental or psychological illness, but for physical illnesses of virtually every description. The health (and healing) of the mind and body have always been intertwined in the practices of both medicine and religion.
The study of religious healing has become a field of increased visibility in a number of disciplines and subfields in the Humanities, Social Sciences, and Psychology, as well is in the field of medical training; indeed, many medical schools today offer courses or programs designed to teach students about the viability of religious or spiritual healing. In this course, we will first examine some of the historical evidence of religious healing, looking at the phenomenon in Christian, Hindu, and Buddhist contexts, as well as in Native American religions and varieties of shamanism. Countless religious and medical texts from all historical periods, as well as ethnographic reports from the last century and a half, exist for all these major religious and healing traditions. In the process of studying this material we will examine notions of science, inquiring into scientific knowledge in cultures with a diverse array of dedicated religious and ritual practices, which is to say in cultures that served as the custodians of this healing knowledge. Examination of some of this vast material will occupy approximately half of this course. We will then draw from modern scientific analysis and practice, including the relatively new field of psycho-neuro-immunology (PNI), which studies the relationship between the mind and the immune system, and from academic appraisals of the nexus or religion and healing. The readings will consist of a mix of primary source material, medical reports, and secondary sources. Several relevant ethnographic videos will also be screened.

name: Love, Marriage, and Family in India
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
This course explores anthropological understandings of love in India and the region of South Asia more broadly, with an emphasis on contemporary society.  Marriage, love and sexuality are deeply embedded in kinship organization, caste, economics, politics and religion.  Topics include filial and motherly love, arranged marriage and romantic love, devotional and artistic expressions, love between siblings.  What are the distinctive roles of courtesan, wife, prostitute—and even ascetic women who renounce family and marriage for a life of celibacy?  Although patrilineal extended family is often idealized as the traditional way of organizing families in India, Pakistan and other South Asian countries, we will also learn about non-dominant forms of love and family (matrilineal, nuclear, etc.) as well as what it means to be a ‘modern’ family in South Asia.
Prerequisite is any introductory course in Anthropology or GWSS, or permission of instructor.

name: Anthro of Beginnings & Ends of Life
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: When does life begin? When does life end?  Surprisingly, these seemingly straightforward questions are the source of controversy and disagreement around the world. In this course, we examine the diverse ways that people understand life and death, and the ways that new medical technologies like prenatal genetic testing and organ transplantation are changing these understandings.  We will also examine how cultural understandings impact the possibilities for a good life and death across racial, class and gender differences.  Throughout the course, we will apply these concepts to analyze current social debates. The course will interest students interested in health, medicine, gender, ethics and global diversity.

name: Peoples and Cultures of Southeast Asia
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course presents a comprehensive introduction to the extraordinary diversity of Southeast Asian peoples and cultures. The area encompasses the nation states of Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam, Brunei, Burma [Myanmar], Cambodia, Laos, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and East Timor. Richly textured ethnographies will be used to discuss themes that include the tapestry of ethnic identities, family cum marriage systems, livelihoods, religious beliefs and social class structures. The challenge is for you to explore the region of Southeast Asia, to conceptualize and understand differences and similarities between socio-cultural systems and human relationships, and above all to ask, "Why?"

name: Animal Bones in Archaeology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course focuses on the analysis of animal bones in archaeological sites. Students will learn mammalian skeletal anatomy and identification, and we will explore a number of issues central to the interpretation of those remains, including taphonomy, determination age and sex, seasonality, quantification and sampling, recognition of breakage and cutmarks, and interpretations. This course involves lecture presentations and laboratory sessions. Laboratory sessions will give hands-on experience in treating archaeological bones and analyzing them.

name: Archaeological Methods
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is an introduction to the practice of archaeology, including class lectures and discussions as well as hands-on laboratory exercises. Students will learn basic techniques in survey, excavation, and analysis.

name: Archaeology of the American Midcontinent
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
View introduction video

This course is a survey of the archaeology of the American Midcontinent for undergraduates and graduate students interested in the past beyond what historical documents reveal. Late Pleistocene and Archaic hunter-gatherer adaptations, Woodland and Late Prehistoric horticulturalists, Middle and Upper Mississippian emergent chiefdoms, and Historic period first contact, fur trade, and fort sites will be explored. Students will learn how archaeologists utilize regional archaeological data in addressing culture change issues to develop the essential grounding for understanding how people lived in different times and places in the past, and how prehistoric peoples relate to their modern descendants across the midcontinent. 
Students are required to participate in two mandatory virtual online meetings, one to prepare for the midterm examination and the other to discuss team projects. 
Note: this course has one proctored online exam. Local students will take exams in the DCE Testing Center (no charge). Off-campus students will take exams using an online proctored exam service. Off-campus students must have access to a computer with a webcam and headset/microphone in a quiet/private location. Off-campus students are responsible for proctoring fees (up to $20 per exam).This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Greek Archaeology and Ethnohistory
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: Introduction to the archaeology of ancient Greece, from prehistoric times to Greece under the Roman empire, including the Minoan and Mycenaean worlds, "Dark Age" Greece, and features of the Archaic, Classical, Hellenistic, and Roman periods.This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Mothers and Motherhood
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description:
Women’s reproductive specialization and their roles as mothers have often been viewed as determinants of their devalued social status.  This course will examine the treatment of mothers and motherhood in feminist theory, in literary works, and in feminist scholarship from such fields as anthropology, sociology, and history.  Current debates over such issues as the feminization of poverty, welfare reform, breastfeeding, child care, and adoption will be explored and related to the ways that motherhood has figured in feminist politics.
 
Course wiki: https://wiki.uiowa.edu/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=116403537

name: Human Osteology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the human skeletal system basic to a variety of disciplines including paleoanthropology, archaeology, forensic anthropology, medical anatomy, exercise science, and biomechanical engineering. Topics covered include basic skeletal anatomy and nomenclature; an introduction to bone microstructure, growth, function, and remodeling; methods for assessing age, sex, biological affinity, cultural and pathological alterations; morphometric measurement and basic quantitative analysis; and the assessment of prehistoric population dynamics. Course format consists of weekly lectures and lab objectives with emphasis on the latter. The majority of class time is spent in hands-on study of human skeletal material.

name: Human Variation
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course examines the range and patterning of biological diversity in contemporary human populations. We will explore past and present attempts to organize and explain human genetic, morphological and behavioral variation in light of recent data and theoretical interpretations, particularly through the current understanding of biocultural processes.

name: Primate Behavior: Sex Lives of Apes
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course will investigate all aspects of non-human primate life. Group and inter-individual behaviors will be presented based on the fundamentals of evolutionary theory and the role of sexual and social interaction in the evolution of higher primates. In addition, an understanding of group structure and mating systems will be reached through an evaluation of ecological constraints imposed on primates in different habitats with an emphasis on the Great Apes. Subjects include: primate taxonomy, diet, predation, cooperation and competition, community ecology, kinship and mating strategies, human-non-human primate interactions, and conservation. The course format includes lectures, discussion, and videos. Requirements include one midterm exam, one take home final exam, and a PowerPoint presentation on a topic of the student's choice.

name: Human Evolutionary Genetics
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The technological advancement of modern genetic and genomic science has revealed much about human evolution in greater detail than ever before imagined. This class will examine current applications of molecular data to questions of human evolution and population genetics. Specific topics include the emergence of modern Homo sapiens, Neanderthal genetics, reconstruction of human migrations, and evidence of natural selection on the human genome. This course will also provide discussion of ancient DNA studies, admixture in modern humans, and molecular genetics of human disease. Students will become familiar with the breadth of genetic data types, including mitochondrial DNA, X- and Y-chromosome markers, nuclear DNA, epigenetic, and various –omic datasets, including genomic, exomic, and transcriptomic.

name: Honors Research Seminar
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course is a seminar for undergraduate students pursuing honors in anthropology. Students enrolled in the course learn the basics of anthropological research design and methods, advanced skills for using key university resources that may be needed for different kinds of honors research (e.g., university libraries, Human Subjects Office/IRB, etc.), and information needed for career development.  A variety of in-class exercises help students to produce either a research proposal or sections of their honors thesis by the end of the semester.

name: Honors Research
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Graduate Teaching Pro-Seminar
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This workshop/seminar is designed to enhance graduate student teaching. The focus is on developing course guidelines, leading discussion, grading, review sessions, and dealing with problem students and complaints. Advanced TAs develop syllabi, teaching portfolios, and mentor less-experienced TAs.

name: Seminar Sociocultural Anthropology                                            Materialist/Explanatory Versus Symbolic/Interpretive Approaches
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: The history of anthropological theory may be seen in terms of a few central and competing approaches that recur over time. This graduate-level seminar will focus on one such ongoing theoretical rivalry—that which pits the materialist/explanatory approach, giving priority to physical environment and infrastructure, against the symbolic/interpretive (or “idealist”) approach, emphasizing the influence of ideas, meanings, and categories. Our readings and discussions will evoke related sets of contrasts within anthropology, such as science versus the humanities, “emic” versus “etic” perspectives, structure versus agency, etc. The seminar is open to graduate students in any field and to anthropology honors undergraduates. It will be useful for students from any discipline in understanding culture as a dynamic process, and for anthropology students wanting to be more firmly grounded in the history of thought in their field.

name: Seminar: Linguistic Anthropology
college: College of Liberal Arts and Sciences
Description: This course introduces graduate students to the fundamental concepts and methods employed in the anthropological study of the language-culture nexus and provides an overview of the principal areas of current research in linguistic anthropology. No previous knowledge of anthropology or linguistics is presumed. The course has a strong historical component which situates several theoretical traditions. Following an introductory consideration of language as a formal system from a semiotic point of view that emphasizes the relationship between form and function, readings turn to issues in linguistic anthropology and ways in which anthropology has construed the relationship between language and culture. Consideration is given to issues of classical and contemporary research, including ethnoscience or lexical semantics, the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis, speech act theory and philosophy of speech, ethnography of speaking, performance and oral poetics, critical discourse analysis, language ideology and metalanguage, and linguistic hegemony and language politics.

name: Bucksbaum Academy Second-Year Seminar
college: University College
Description: This seminar is designed for students in their second year of the Bucksbaum Academy, and early-entrance program supported by the Belin-Blank Center. The purpose of the seminar is to unite the self-efficacy skills attained in the first-year seminar experience with the exploration of how to foster more fulfilling and productive lives, and the understanding and development of high potential. Through a series of portfolio assignments, the seminar provides students an opportunity to re-evaluate their beliefs, values, and assumptions, while taking on the challenge of improving the world. The skills of building, journaling, storytelling, and public speaking, among others, will be explored throughout the semesterIf you are not a member of the University of Iowa Honors Program, you may contact the course instructor in order to request permission to enroll.

name: IBA Student Development Seminar                                            Professionalism in the Scientific Community
college: University College
Description: This seminar is designed to foster the professional development of students in the Iowa Biosciences Academy program. Course format consists of a series of presentations, workshops, and discussions by biomedical research faculty, IBA staff, and others. Attendance is mandatory. Readings may be required.

name: IBA Student Development Seminar                                            IBA Scholar Seminar
college: University College
Description:
Critical Analysis of Research
The purpose of this seminar is to develop undergraduate students’ critical thinking and research skills through intensive analysis of primary literature to demystify and humanize research science.  Students will be instructed on how to analyze the components of a good empirical article. To better prepare the students for their contribution to future empirical manuscripts, students will be asked to present a research paper from literature in their field of interest once during the semester and prepare a critical analysis of a primary research paper.  The week before their presentation is to be made, the students meet with one of the coordinators to discuss any questions they have about the article and to receive input on their electronic presentation.
The student presenting is also responsible for creating a list of questions focused on key techniques and scientific principles discussed in the article. These questions, along with the selected research article, are distributed in advance to the other IBA scholars, who are each assigned one question to which they must respond during the presentation. This process ensures that all students become “experts” in one aspect of the presentation and that they are actively engaged in each of the presentations.
Each student will also be required to give a 5-7 minute short talk on their research.  This talk will be practice for the Scholar Symposium event held at the end of the semester.

name: IBA Research in Biomedical Science
college: University College
Description: This course enables students in the IBA program to receive credit for their required work in the biomedical laboratories of their mentors. Students are expected to work at least 5 hours per week in the laboratory. Students must negotiate terms of their work arrangement with the appropriate faculty/researcher and the IBA program.If you have not received permission from the instructor to add this section, your enrollment may be administratively dropped.

name: Principles of Biomedical Science
college: University College
Description: Students explore concepts of biology and medicine to determine factors that led to the death of a fictional person. While investigating the case, students examine autopsy reports, investigate medical history, and explore medical treatments that might have prolonged the person’s life. The activities and projects introduce students to human physiology, basic biology, medicine, and research processes while allowing them to design their own experiments to solve problems.Contact Project Lead the Way, 3016 SC, to override registration restriction.

name: Human Body Systems
college: University College
Description: Students examine the interactions of human body systems as they explore identity, power, movement, protection, and homeostasis. Exploring science in action, students build organs and tissues on a skeletal manikin; use data acquisition software to monitor body functions such as muscle movement, reflex and voluntary action, and respiration; and take on the roles of biomedical professionals to solve real-world medical cases.Contact Project Lead the Way, 3016 SC, to override registration restriction.

name: Medical Interventions
college: University College
Description: Students follow the life of a fictitious family as they investigate how to prevent, diagnose, and treat disease. Students explore how to detect and fight infection; screen and evaluate the code in human DNA; evaluate cancer treatment options; and prevail when the organs of the body begin to fail. Through real-world cases, students are exposed to a range of interventions related to immunology, surgery, genetics, pharmacology, medical devices, and diagnostics.Contact Project Lead the Way, 3016 SC, to override registration restriction.

name: Biomedical Innovation
college: University College
Description: Capstone course in which students build on the knowledge and skills gained from previous PLTW courses to design innovative solutions for the most pressing health challenges of the 21st century. Students address topics ranging from public health and biomedical engineering to clinical medicine and physiology. They have the opportunity to work on an independent design project with a mentor or advisor from a university, medical facility, or research institution.Contact Project Lead the Way, 3016 SC, to override registration restriction.

name: Social Skills I
college: College of Education
Description: This course was compiled to provide useful tools to communicate effectively.  Activities will begin with defining basic types of communication which include passive, aggressive and assertive methods. Students will engage in individual and group activities to increase awareness of changing environments and types of communication.  This class, taught in seminar fashion, will assist students in identifying their own communication styles, and adapting current behaviors to better communicate their needs. Students will move into the community and workplace to observe and practice new communication methods.

name: Computers and Technology I
college: College of Education
Description: This foundations course provides essential training on computer parts and functions, the Windows operating system, and computer applications.  The course seeks to improve computer literacy and practical skills for computer use in everyday life.  Course instruction integrates group discussion, demonstration, and a multi-media experience to support diverse learning styles.  This course encourages the use of a personal computer as a tool to improve personal, academic, and workplace productivity.

name: Health and Wellness I-Exploration
college: College of Education
Description: This introductory course in health and personal wellness is designed to assist students in understanding the 7 dimensions of wellness and health awareness.  This seminar provides an overview of topics including: nutrition; responsible sexual behavior; consequences of substance use; and disease prevention.  This information will help students become more knowledgeable about their own emotional, mental, and physical health.  The course provides a framework for further exploration in health and wellness in everyday life.  This multidisciplinary course will integrate skills learned in Tools for Life, Communication, Daily Living Skills, and Healthy Relationships.

name: Health/Wellness II--Healthy Lifestyles
college: College of Education

name: Personal Finance and Math I
college: College of Education
Description: First of a 2 part series, this course examines the student’s understanding of numbers, operations, and managing personal finances.  Course topics include; computation strategies, problem solving strategies, and skills to be good consumers.  The student will practice these math skills as needed in the community and the workplace.

name: Personal Finance and Math II
college: College of Education

name: Life Skills I--Transitions
college: College of Education
Description: The course focuses on the components of successful independent and community living.  The course includes a student-developed plan for personal daily routines. The course emphasizes personal safety issues and effective communication skills for interacting with peers and college personnel.  Students are learn to access broader community resources for living, work, and leisure.  Instruction includes classroom activities, with time spent in practical experiences on campus and in the community.

name: Career Exploration
college: College of Education
Description: This course is designed to allow students to explore, enhance or broaden their work interests, skills, and potential career opportunities.  Course topics include interest inventories, a review of vocational experiences, interactive employer presentations, informational interviews, and job shadow experiences.  This foundation course emphasizes the self-assessment of a student’s individual vocational strengths to assist the students in making informed career decisions.

name: Bioinformatics Techniques
college: College of Engineering
Description: This course provides a more specific treatment of informatics tools and techniques as they apply to modern problems in biomedicine and basic life sciences. The course builds on computational (programming) and bioscience (genetics/genomics) topics. It seeks to provide broad exposure to common tools, and provide enough experience in applying them to contemporary problem settings to serve as a gateway to electives in Bioinformatics. For students who already have a software and computing background (have taken at least ENGR:1300 and ENGR:2730 or equivalent), this course provides a solid bio-context for using those previously developed skills. Students who do not have any previous computing experience should not take this course. Topics include: Tools at the developer level: UNIX, BioPerl, BLAST/BLAT, R, web-based tools, Apache, PHP, etc. Common Data Models: NCBI/EMBL, sequence, expression, proteomics, systems biology/pathways, clinical information, genotyping, structural chemistry (pdb), etc. Data Analysis and Annotation: e.g., transcription and expression, genomics, proteomics, clustering, basic linkage, comparative genomics, statistical genetics. Common access and APIs to data repositories and results: Interface design, submission protocols, data exchange formats, web services, etc. LIMS: Laboratory Information Management Systems: Raw experimental data, protocol management, experiment design specifications.

name: Fundamentals of Software Engineering
college: College of Engineering
Description: This course is an introduction to the software engineering process. Students examine lifecycle phases: problem analysis, requirements definition, specification, design, implementation, testing/maintenance, integration, and project management. In addition, human factors, software validation and verification, and group project experience are examined. Requirements include four homework exercises, a semester-long project, and two exams (one midterm and a final).  Students should have significant exposure to database systems, programming, and preferably have undergraduate senior or graduate standing. The course is taught by a faculty member.

name: Formal Methods in Software Engineering
college: College of Engineering
Description: This course introduces formal models, methods, and their application in various phases of software engineering process. The purpose of formal methods is to enable the construction of large, highly reliable software. Their foundation is the precise specification of the run-time properties that a software system is expected to satisfy. The course presents a collection of techniques for formal software development including operational, algebraic, model-based, property-based specification methods; for the verification of consistency and completeness of specifications; for the verification of software properties. Course work includes exercises in specification construction and verification, both on paper and using formal method-based tools. The course is taught by a faculty member. Same as ECE:5810.This section is offered through Distance and Online Education.  Current UI students should register directly on MyUI.  Students who are not admitted to the UI click here to proceed. Contact 319-335-2575 or dce-registration@uiowa.edu for assistance.

name: Software Engineering Languages and Tools
college: College of Engineering
Description: Focus on modern agile software development practices for cloud and web-based applications, using state-of-the-art software engineering languages, tools and technologies.Topics covered in the revised course will include:1. Agile Software Development Practicesa. Behavior-driven Designb. Test-driven Developmentc. Refactoringd. Pair programminge. Teams and collaborative development: version control, configuration management2. Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) Architecturea. Architectural patterns for SaaS: Client-Server, Tiered, Model-View-Controller (MVC)b. RESTful servicesc. Data management and CRUD 3. The Ruby on Rails Development Frameworka. The Ruby language (“More powerful that Perl, more object-oriented than Python”)b. The Rails framework for web application development and deploymentc. Rails tools: Cucumber, Capybara, rSpec , …4. Developing SaaS applications using Ruby and Railsa. SaaS Design Patternsb. Incorporating JavaScript and AJAXc. Web app performance and security issuesText:  Engineering Long-Lasting Software: An Agile Approach using SaaS and Cloud Computing (Beta Edition) by Armando Fox and David Patterson, available for Kindle, iPad, Nook, as well as in print form.  Electronic formats are strongly preferred as they offer interactive options not available in the print edition.Projects and Homework: The course will involve both individual and group homework and project activity including at least one substantial group project.Expected Background:  a solid understanding of object-oriented design and programming, and facility with at least one object-oriented programming language is essential.  Any student who is interested in taking the course but has not completed the prerequisite should contact Prof. Jon Kuhl at: kuhl@engineering.uiowa.edu

name: Contemp Topics in Elect & Computer Eng                                            Detection and Estimation Theory: Statistical Decision Theory for Electrical Engineers
college: College of Engineering
Description:
This course is intended to provide a rigorous and formal introduction to the science of statistical reasoning, broadly speaking, as used in different ECE sub-disciplines. Specifically, students who wish to take future elective ECE classes on Communication Theory, Control Theory, Pattern Recognition, Image Processing and Digital Signal Processing may find this class to be useful. However, more broadly, our aim is to introduce the fundamental theoretical underpinnings of modern “data science” and “machine learning” methods.
 
The class is targeted at upper-level undergraduate and graduate students. Students enrolling in this class must be familiar with basic signals and systems and probability concepts. Specifically, a working knowledge of Fourier series and transforms, linear filtering, random variables and probability densities and distributions is essential. However, knowledge of more advanced concepts such as sampling theory, random processes and characteristic functions will not be assumed.
 
This class will be unapologetically abstract and mathematical; it is not “hands-on” in any way, there are no labs and while there will be references to practical applications, that is explicitly not the focus of this class. The class will be lecture based with weekly Homework including some computational assignments that will require the use of MATLAB (or similar) software.
 
A tentative list of topics is as follows:1. Axioms of probability; random variables and distributions; the philosophy of probability; Bayesian v. frequentist approaches to probability; likelihood v. probability; puzzles and paradoxes2. Densities, distributions and characteristic functions; the Law of Large Numbers; Chebyshev and Chernoff Bounds; multi-variate Gaussian rvs; the Central Limit Theorem3. Stochastic processes; stationarity and ergodicity; autocorrelation, cross-correlation and spectral densities; Gaussian processes; Markov chains4. The problem of parameter estimation; concept of sufficient statistics; minimality and unbiasedness; linear estimators; minimum-variance unbiased estimators5. The problem of detection or hypothesis testing; the Neyman-Pearson lemma; recever-operating characteristics; detection with Gaussian processes; the matched filter6. Likelihood functions; the maximum likelihood principle; the Fisher Matrix and the Cramer-Rao Lower Bound; ML-identification of linear systems7. Monte-Carlo methods; importance sampling and particle filtering8. Non-parametric detection and estimation; principal component analysis; independent component analysis; support vector machines
